That nature must compel us to lament
Our most persisted deeds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MECAENAS
SPEECH.LINE: His taints and honours
Waged equal with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGRIPPA
SPEECH.LINE: A rarer spirit never
Did steer humanity: but you, gods, will give us
Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touch'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MECAENAS
SPEECH.LINE: When such a spacious mirror's set before him,
He needs must see himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: O Antony!
I have follow'd thee to this; but we do lance
Diseases in our bodies: I must perforce
Have shown to thee such a declining day,
Or look on thine; we could not stall together
In the whole world: but yet let me lament,
With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts,
That thou, my brother, my competitor
In top of all design, my mate in empire,
Friend and companion in the front of war,
The arm of mine own body, and the heart
Where mine his thoughts did kindle,--that our stars,
Unreconciliable, should divide
Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends--
But I will tell you at some meeter season:
The business of this man looks out of him;
We'll hear him what he says. Whence are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Egyptian
SPEECH.LINE: A poor Egyptian yet. The queen my mistress,
Confined in all she has, her monument,
Of thy intents desires instruction,
That she preparedly may frame herself
To the way she's forced to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Bid her have good heart:
She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,
How honourable and how kindly we
Determine for her; for Caesar cannot live
To be ungentle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Egyptian
SPEECH.LINE: So the gods preserve thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say,
We purpose her no shame: give her what comforts
The quality of her passion shall require,
Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke
She do defeat us; for her life in Rome
Would be eternal in our triumph: go,
And with your speediest bring us what she says,
And how you find of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, I shall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Gallus, go you along.
Where's Dolabella,
To second Proculeius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Dolabella!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Let him alone, for I remember now
How he's employ'd: he shall in time be ready.
Go with me to my tent; where you shall see
How hardly I was drawn into this war;
How calm and gentle I proceeded still
In all my writings: go with me, and see
What I can show in this.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. Alexandria. A room in the monument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: My desolation does begin to make
A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar;
Not being Fortune, he's but Fortune's knave,
A minister of her will: and it is great
To do that thing that ends all other deeds;
Which shackles accidents and bolts up change;
Which sleeps, and never palates more the dug,
The beggar's nurse and Caesar's.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, to the gates of the monument, PROCULEIUS, GALLUS and Soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt;
And bids thee study on what fair demands
Thou mean'st to have him grant thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: What's thy name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: My name is Proculeius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Antony
Did tell me of you, bade me trust you; but
I do not greatly care to be deceived,
That have no use for trusting. If your master
Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him,
That majesty, to keep decorum, must
No less beg than a kingdom: if he please
To give me conquer'd Egypt for my son,
He gives me so much of mine own, as I
Will kneel to him with thanks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Be of good cheer;
You're fall'n into a princely hand, fear nothing:
Make your full reference freely to my lord,
Who is so full of grace, that it flows over
On all that need: let me report to him
Your sweet dependency; and you shall find
A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness,
Where he for grace is kneel'd to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you, tell him
I am his fortune's vassal, and I send him
The greatness he has got. I hourly learn
A doctrine of obedience; and would gladly
Look him i' the face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This I'll report, dear lady.
Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied
Of him that caused it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GALLUS
SPEECH.LINE: You see how easily she may be surprised:
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Here PROCULEIUS and two of the Guard ascend the monument by a ladder placed against a window, and, having descended, come behind CLEOPATRA. Some of the Guard unbar and open the gates
SPEECH.LINE: Guard her till Caesar come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: IRAS
SPEECH.LINE: Royal queen!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: O Cleopatra! thou art taken, queen:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Quick, quick, good hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hold, worthy lady, hold:
Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this
Relieved, but not betray'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: What, of death too,
That rids our dogs of languish?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Cleopatra,
Do not abuse my master's bounty by
The undoing of yourself: let the world see
His nobleness well acted, which your death
Will never let come forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Where art thou, death?
Come hither, come! come, come, and take a queen
Worthy many babes and beggars!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, temperance, lady!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I will eat no meat, I'll not drink, sir;
If idle talk will once be necessary,
I'll not sleep neither: this mortal house I'll ruin,
Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I
Will not wait pinion'd at your master's court;
Nor once be chastised with the sober eye
Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up
And show me to the shouting varletry
Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt
Be gentle grave unto me! rather on Nilus' mud
Lay me stark naked, and let the water-flies
Blow me into abhorring! rather make
My country's high pyramides my gibbet,
And hang me up in chains!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You do extend
These thoughts of horror further than you shall
Find cause in Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Proculeius,
What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows,
And he hath sent for thee: for the queen,
I'll take her to my guard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PROCULEIUS
SPEECH.LINE: So, Dolabella,
It shall content me best: be gentle to her.
To Caesar I will speak what you shall please,
If you'll employ me to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Say, I would die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Most noble empress, you have heard of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Assuredly you know me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: No matter, sir, what I have heard or known.
You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams;
Is't not your trick?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: I understand not, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: I dream'd there was an Emperor Antony:
O, such another sleep, that I might see
But such another man!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: If it might please ye,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: His face was as the heavens; and therein stuck
A sun and moon, which kept their course,
and lighted
The little O, the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Most sovereign creature,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: His legs bestrid the ocean: his rear'd arm
Crested the world: his voice was propertied
As all the tuned spheres, and that to friends;
But when he meant to quail and shake the orb,
He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty,
There was no winter in't; an autumn 'twas
That grew the more by reaping: his delights
Were dolphin-like; they show'd his back above
The element they lived in: in his livery
Walk'd crowns and crownets; realms and islands were
As plates dropp'd from his pocket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Cleopatra!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Think you there was, or might be, such a man
As this I dream'd of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle madam, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: You lie, up to the hearing of the gods.
But, if there be, or ever were, one such,
It's past the size of dreaming: nature wants stuff
To vie strange forms with fancy; yet, to imagine
And Antony, were nature's piece 'gainst fancy,
Condemning shadows quite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Hear me, good madam.
Your loss is as yourself, great; and you bear it
As answering to the weight: would I might never
O'ertake pursued success, but I do feel,
By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites
My very heart at root.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you, sir,
Know you what Caesar means to do with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, pray you, sir,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Though he be honourable,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: He'll lead me, then, in triumph?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, he will; I know't.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish, and shout within, 'Make way there: Octavius Caesar!'
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, GALLUS, PROCULEIUS, MECAENAS, SELEUCUS, and others of his Train

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Which is the Queen of Egypt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: It is the emperor, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Arise, you shall not kneel:
I pray you, rise; rise, Egypt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the gods
Will have it thus; my master and my lord
I must obey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Take to you no hard thoughts:
The record of what injuries you did us,
Though written in our flesh, we shall remember
As things but done by chance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Sole sir o' the world,
I cannot project mine own cause so well
To make it clear; but do confess I have
Been laden with like frailties which before
Have often shamed our sex.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Cleopatra, know,
We will extenuate rather than enforce:
If you apply yourself to our intents,
Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find
A benefit in this change; but if you seek
To lay on me a cruelty, by taking
Antony's course, you shall bereave yourself
Of my good purposes, and put your children
To that destruction which I'll guard them from,
If thereon you rely. I'll take my leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: And may, through all the world: 'tis yours; and we,
Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall
Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels,
I am possess'd of: 'tis exactly valued;
Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SELEUCUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: This is my treasurer: let him speak, my lord,
Upon his peril, that I have reserved
To myself nothing. Speak the truth, Seleucus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SELEUCUS
SPEECH.LINE: Madam,
I had rather seal my lips, than, to my peril,
Speak that which is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: What have I kept back?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SELEUCUS
SPEECH.LINE: Enough to purchase what you have made known.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra; I approve
Your wisdom in the deed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: See, Caesar! O, behold,
How pomp is follow'd! mine will now be yours;
And, should we shift estates, yours would be mine.
The ingratitude of this Seleucus does
Even make me wild: O slave, of no more trust
Than love that's hired! What, goest thou back? thou shalt
Go back, I warrant thee; but I'll catch thine eyes,
Though they had wings: slave, soulless villain, dog!
O rarely base!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Good queen, let us entreat you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this,
That thou, vouchsafing here to visit me,
Doing the honour of thy lordliness
To one so meek, that mine own servant should
Parcel the sum of my disgraces by
Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar,
That I some lady trifles have reserved,
Immoment toys, things of such dignity
As we greet modern friends withal; and say,
Some nobler token I have kept apart
For Livia and Octavia, to induce
Their mediation; must I be unfolded
With one that I have bred? The gods! it smites me
Beneath the fall I have.
Prithee, go hence;
Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits
Through the ashes of my chance: wert thou a man,
Thou wouldst have mercy on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Forbear, Seleucus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Be it known, that we, the greatest, are misthought
For things that others do; and, when we fall,
We answer others' merits in our name,
Are therefore to be pitied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Cleopatra,
Not what you have reserved, nor what acknowledged,
Put we i' the roll of conquest: still be't yours,
Bestow it at your pleasure; and believe,
Caesar's no merchant, to make prize with you
Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheer'd;
Make not your thoughts your prisons: no, dear queen;
For we intend so to dispose you as
Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed, and sleep:
Our care and pity is so much upon you,
That we remain your friend; and so, adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: My master, and my lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Not so. Adieu.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Exeunt OCTAVIUS CAESAR and his train

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not
Be noble to myself: but, hark thee, Charmian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: IRAS
SPEECH.LINE: Finish, good lady; the bright day is done,
And we are for the dark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Hie thee again:
I have spoke already, and it is provided;
Go put it to the haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the queen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: Behold, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Dolabella!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, as thereto sworn by your command,
Which my love makes religion to obey,
I tell you this: Caesar through Syria
Intends his journey; and within three days
You with your children will he send before:
Make your best use of this: I have perform'd
Your pleasure and my promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Dolabella,
I shall remain your debtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: I your servant,
Adieu, good queen; I must attend on Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, and thanks.
Now, Iras, what think'st thou?
Thou, an Egyptian puppet, shalt be shown
In Rome, as well as I mechanic slaves
With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers, shall
Uplift us to the view; in their thick breaths,
Rank of gross diet, shall be enclouded,
And forced to drink their vapour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: IRAS
SPEECH.LINE: The gods forbid!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, 'tis most certain, Iras: saucy lictors
Will catch at us, like strumpets; and scald rhymers
Ballad us out o' tune: the quick comedians
Extemporally will stage us, and present
Our Alexandrian revels; Antony
Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see
Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness
I' the posture of a whore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: IRAS
SPEECH.LINE: O the good gods!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that's certain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: IRAS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll never see 't; for, I am sure, my nails
Are stronger than mine eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, that's the way
To fool their preparation, and to conquer
Their most absurd intents.
Now, Charmian!
Show me, my women, like a queen: go fetch
My best attires: I am again for Cydnus,
To meet Mark Antony: sirrah Iras, go.
Now, noble Charmian, we'll dispatch indeed;
And, when thou hast done this chare, I'll give thee leave
To play till doomsday. Bring our crown and all.
Wherefore's this noise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guard
SPEECH.LINE: Here is a rural fellow
That will not be denied your highness presence:
He brings you figs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Let him come in.
What poor an instrument
May do a noble deed! he brings me liberty.
My resolution's placed, and I have nothing
Of woman in me: now from head to foot
I am marble-constant; now the fleeting moon
No planet is of mine.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter Guardsman, with Clown bringing in a basket

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guard
SPEECH.LINE: This is the man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Avoid, and leave him.
Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there,
That kills and pains not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, I have him: but I would not be the party
that should desire you to touch him, for his biting
is immortal; those that do die of it do seldom or
never recover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Rememberest thou any that have died on't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of
them no longer than yesterday: a very honest woman,
but something given to lie; as a woman should not
do, but in the way of honesty: how she died of the
biting of it, what pain she felt: truly, she makes
a very good report o' the worm; but he that will
believe all that they say, shall never be saved by
half that they do: but this is most fallible, the
worm's an odd worm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Get thee hence; farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: I wish you all joy of the worm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: You must think this, look you, that the worm will
do his kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, ay; farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the
keeping of wise people; for, indeed, there is no
goodness in worm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Take thou no care; it shall be heeded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is
not worth the feeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Will it eat me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: You must not think I am so simple but I know the
devil himself will not eat a woman: I know that a
woman is a dish for the gods, if the devil dress her
not. But, truly, these same whoreson devils do the
gods great harm in their women; for in every ten
that they make, the devils mar five.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Well, get thee gone; farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, forsooth: I wish you joy o' the worm.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter IRAS with a robe, crown, c

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Give me my robe, put on my crown; I have
Immortal longings in me: now no more
The juice of Egypt's grape shall moist this lip:
Yare, yare, good Iras; quick. Methinks I hear
Antony call; I see him rouse himself
To praise my noble act; I hear him mock
The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men
To excuse their after wrath: husband, I come:
Now to that name my courage prove my title!
I am fire and air; my other elements
I give to baser life. So; have you done?
Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips.
Farewell, kind Charmian; Iras, long farewell.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Kisses them. IRAS falls and dies
SPEECH.LINE: Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
If thou and nature can so gently part,
The stroke of death is as a lover's pinch,
Which hurts, and is desired. Dost thou lie still?
If thus thou vanishest, thou tell'st the world
It is not worth leave-taking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain; that I may say,
The gods themselves do weep!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: This proves me base:
If she first meet the curled Antony,
He'll make demand of her, and spend that kiss
Which is my heaven to have. Come, thou
mortal wretch,
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: To an asp, which she applies to her breast
SPEECH.LINE: With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate
Of life at once untie: poor venomous fool
Be angry, and dispatch. O, couldst thou speak,
That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass
Unpolicied!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: O eastern star!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace!
Dost thou not see my baby at my breast,
That sucks the nurse asleep?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: O, break! O, break!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLEOPATRA
SPEECH.LINE: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle,--
O Antony!--Nay, I will take thee too.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Applying another asp to her arm
SPEECH.LINE: What should I stay--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: In this vile world? So, fare thee well.
Now boast thee, death, in thy possession lies
A lass unparallel'd. Downy windows, close;
And golden Phoebus never be beheld
Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry;
I'll mend it, and then play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Guard
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the queen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: Speak softly, wake her not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Guard
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar hath sent--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: Too slow a messenger.
O, come apace, dispatch! I partly feel thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Guard
SPEECH.LINE: Approach, ho! All's not well: Caesar's beguiled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Guard
SPEECH.LINE: There's Dolabella sent from Caesar; call him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Guard
SPEECH.LINE: What work is here! Charmian, is this well done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARMIAN
SPEECH.LINE: It is well done, and fitting for a princess
Descended of so many royal kings.
Ah, soldier!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: How goes it here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Guard
SPEECH.LINE: All dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, thy thoughts
Touch their effects in this: thyself art coming
To see perform'd the dreaded act which thou
So sought'st to hinder.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Within 'A way there, a way for Caesar!'
Re-enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR and all his train marching

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: O sir, you are too sure an augurer;
That you did fear is done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Bravest at the last,
She levell'd at our purposes, and, being royal,
Took her own way. The manner of their deaths?
I do not see them bleed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Who was last with them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Guard
SPEECH.LINE: A simple countryman, that brought her figs:
This was his basket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Poison'd, then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Guard
SPEECH.LINE: O Caesar,
This Charmian lived but now; she stood and spake:
I found her trimming up the diadem
On her dead mistress; tremblingly she stood
And on the sudden dropp'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: O noble weakness!
If they had swallow'd poison, 'twould appear
By external swelling: but she looks like sleep,
As she would catch another Antony
In her strong toil of grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DOLABELLA
SPEECH.LINE: Here, on her breast,
There is a vent of blood and something blown:
The like is on her arm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Guard
SPEECH.LINE: This is an aspic's trail: and these fig-leaves
Have slime upon them, such as the aspic leaves
Upon the caves of Nile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Most probable
That so she died; for her physician tells me
She hath pursued conclusions infinite
Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed;
And bear her women from the monument:
She shall be buried by her Antony:
No grave upon the earth shall clip in it
A pair so famous. High events as these
Strike those that make them; and their story is
No less in pity than his glory which
Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall
In solemn show attend this funeral;
And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see
High order in this great solemnity.

PERSONAE.TITLE: Dramatis Personae

PGROUP.GRPDESCR: servants to the Countess of Rousillon.

PERSONAE.PERSONA: COUNTESS OF ROUSILLON, mother to Bertram.
HELENA, a gentlewoman protected by the Countess.

PGROUP.GRPDESCR: neighbours and friends to the Widow.

PERSONAE.PERSONA: Lords, Officers, Soldiers, c., French and Florentine.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: And I in going, madam, weep o'er my father's death
anew: but I must attend his majesty's command, to
whom I am now in ward, evermore in subjection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: You shall find of the king a husband, madam; you,
sir, a father: he that so generally is at all times
good must of necessity hold his virtue to you; whose
worthiness would stir it up where it wanted rather
than lack it where there is such abundance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: What hope is there of his majesty's amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: He hath abandoned his physicians, madam; under whose
practises he hath persecuted time with hope, and
finds no other advantage in the process but only the
losing of hope by time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: This young gentlewoman had a father,--O, that
'had'! how sad a passage 'tis!--whose skill was
almost as great as his honesty; had it stretched so
far, would have made nature immortal, and death
should have play for lack of work. Would, for the
king's sake, he were living! I think it would be
the death of the king's disease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: How called you the man you speak of, madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it was
his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: He was excellent indeed, madam: the king very
lately spoke of him admiringly and mourningly: he
was skilful enough to have lived still, if knowledge
could be set up against mortality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: What is it, my good lord, the king languishes of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: A fistula, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: I heard not of it before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman
the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my
overlooking. I have those hopes of her good that
her education promises; her dispositions she
inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer; for where
an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities, there
commendations go with pity; they are virtues and
traitors too; in her they are the better for their
simpleness; she derives her honesty and achieves her goodness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Your commendations, madam, get from her tears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise
in. The remembrance of her father never approaches
her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows takes all
livelihood from her cheek. No more of this, Helena;
go to, no more; lest it be rather thought you affect
a sorrow than have it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,
excessive grief the enemy to the living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: If the living be enemy to the grief, the excess
makes it soon mortal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: How understand we that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father
In manners, as in shape! thy blood and virtue
Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness
Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few,
Do wrong to none: be able for thine enemy
Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend
Under thy own life's key: be cheque'd for silence,
But never tax'd for speech. What heaven more will,
That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down,
Fall on thy head! Farewell, my lord;
'Tis an unseason'd courtier; good my lord,
Advise him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot want the best
That shall attend his love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: To HELENA The best wishes that can be forged in
your thoughts be servants to you! Be comfortable
to my mother, your mistress, and make much of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, pretty lady: you must hold the credit of
your father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: O, were that all! I think not on my father;
And these great tears grace his remembrance more
Than those I shed for him. What was he like?
I have forgot him: my imagination
Carries no favour in't but Bertram's.
I am undone: there is no living, none,
If Bertram be away. 'Twere all one
That I should love a bright particular star
And think to wed it, he is so above me:
In his bright radiance and collateral light
Must I be comforted, not in his sphere.
The ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
The hind that would be mated by the lion
Must die for love. 'Twas pretty, though plague,
To see him every hour; to sit and draw
His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls,
In our heart's table; heart too capable
Of every line and trick of his sweet favour:
But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy
Must sanctify his reliques. Who comes here?
One that goes with him: I love him for his sake;
And yet I know him a notorious liar,
Think him a great way fool, solely a coward;
Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him,
That they take place, when virtue's steely bones
Look bleak i' the cold wind: withal, full oft we see
Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Save you, fair queen!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: And you, monarch!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: And no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Are you meditating on virginity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you: let me
ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity; how
may we barricado it against him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Keep him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: But he assails; and our virginity, though valiant,
in the defence yet is weak: unfold to us some
warlike resistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: There is none: man, sitting down before you, will
undermine you and blow you up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Bless our poor virginity from underminers and
blowers up! Is there no military policy, how
virgins might blow up men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be
blown up: marry, in blowing him down again, with
the breach yourselves made, you lose your city. It
is not politic in the commonwealth of nature to
preserve virginity. Loss of virginity is rational
increase and there was never virgin got till
virginity was first lost. That you were made of is
metal to make virgins. Virginity by being once lost
may be ten times found; by being ever kept, it is
ever lost: 'tis too cold a companion; away with 't!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: I will stand for 't a little, though therefore I die a virgin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: There's little can be said in 't; 'tis against the
rule of nature. To speak on the part of virginity,
is to accuse your mothers; which is most infallible
disobedience. He that hangs himself is a virgin:
virginity murders itself and should be buried in
highways out of all sanctified limit, as a desperate
offendress against nature. Virginity breeds mites,
much like a cheese; consumes itself to the very
paring, and so dies with feeding his own stomach.
Besides, virginity is peevish, proud, idle, made of
self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the
canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but loose
by't: out with 't! within ten year it will make
itself ten, which is a goodly increase; and the
principal itself not much the worse: away with 't!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Let me see: marry, ill, to like him that ne'er it
likes. 'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with
lying; the longer kept, the less worth: off with 't
while 'tis vendible; answer the time of request.
Virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap out
of fashion: richly suited, but unsuitable: just
like the brooch and the tooth-pick, which wear not
now. Your date is better in your pie and your
porridge than in your cheek; and your virginity,
your old virginity, is like one of our French
withered pears, it looks ill, it eats drily; marry,
'tis a withered pear; it was formerly better;
marry, yet 'tis a withered pear: will you anything with it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Not my virginity yet
There shall your master have a thousand loves,
A mother and a mistress and a friend,
A phoenix, captain and an enemy,
A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign,
A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear;
His humble ambition, proud humility,
His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet,
His faith, his sweet disaster; with a world
Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms,
That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he--
I know not what he shall. God send him well!
The court's a learning place, and he is one--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: What one, i' faith?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: That I wish well. 'Tis pity--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: What's pity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: That wishing well had not a body in't,
Which might be felt; that we, the poorer born,
Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,
Might with effects of them follow our friends,
And show what we alone must think, which never
Return us thanks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page
SPEECH.LINE: Monsieur Parolles, my lord calls for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Little Helen, farewell; if I can remember thee, I
will think of thee at court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a charitable star.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Under Mars, I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: I especially think, under Mars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Why under Mars?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: The wars have so kept you under that you must needs
be born under Mars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: When he was predominant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: When he was retrograde, I think, rather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Why think you so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: You go so much backward when you fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: That's for advantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: So is running away, when fear proposes the safety;
but the composition that your valour and fear makes
in you is a virtue of a good wing, and I like the wear well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: I am so full of businesses, I cannot answer thee
acutely. I will return perfect courtier; in the
which, my instruction shall serve to naturalize
thee, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier's
counsel and understand what advice shall thrust upon
thee; else thou diest in thine unthankfulness, and
thine ignorance makes thee away: farewell. When
thou hast leisure, say thy prayers; when thou hast
none, remember thy friends; get thee a good husband,
and use him as he uses thee; so, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie,
Which we ascribe to heaven: the fated sky
Gives us free scope, only doth backward pull
Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.
What power is it which mounts my love so high,
That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye?
The mightiest space in fortune nature brings
To join like likes and kiss like native things.
Impossible be strange attempts to those
That weigh their pains in sense and do suppose
What hath been cannot be: who ever strove
So show her merit, that did miss her love?
The king's disease--my project may deceive me,
But my intents are fix'd and will not leave me.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: The Florentines and Senoys are by the ears;
Have fought with equal fortune and continue
A braving war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: So 'tis reported, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, 'tis most credible; we here received it
A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria,
With caution that the Florentine will move us
For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend
Prejudicates the business and would seem
To have us make denial.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: His love and wisdom,
Approved so to your majesty, may plead
For amplest credence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: He hath arm'd our answer,
And Florence is denied before he comes:
Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to see
The Tuscan service, freely have they leave
To stand on either part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Lord
SPEECH.LINE: It well may serve
A nursery to our gentry, who are sick
For breathing and exploit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: What's he comes here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: It is the Count Rousillon, my good lord,
Young Bertram.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face;
Frank nature, rather curious than in haste,
Hath well composed thee. Thy father's moral parts
Mayst thou inherit too! Welcome to Paris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: My thanks and duty are your majesty's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had that corporal soundness now,
As when thy father and myself in friendship
First tried our soldiership! He did look far
Into the service of the time and was
Discipled of the bravest: he lasted long;
But on us both did haggish age steal on
And wore us out of act. It much repairs me
To talk of your good father. In his youth
He had the wit which I can well observe
To-day in our young lords; but they may jest
Till their own scorn return to them unnoted
Ere they can hide their levity in honour;
So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness
Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were,
His equal had awaked them, and his honour,
Clock to itself, knew the true minute when
Exception bid him speak, and at this time
His tongue obey'd his hand: who were below him
He used as creatures of another place
And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks,
Making them proud of his humility,
In their poor praise he humbled. Such a man
Might be a copy to these younger times;
Which, follow'd well, would demonstrate them now
But goers backward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: His good remembrance, sir,
Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb;
So in approof lives not his epitaph
As in your royal speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Would I were with him! He would always say--
Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words
He scatter'd not in ears, but grafted them,
To grow there and to bear,--'Let me not live,'--
This his good melancholy oft began,
On the catastrophe and heel of pastime,
When it was out,--'Let me not live,' quoth he,
'After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff
Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
All but new things disdain; whose judgments are
Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies
Expire before their fashions.' This he wish'd;
I after him do after him wish too,
Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home,
I quickly were dissolved from my hive,
To give some labourers room.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Lord
SPEECH.LINE: You are loved, sir:
They that least lend it you shall lack you first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: I fill a place, I know't. How long is't, count,
Since the physician at your father's died?
He was much famed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: Some six months since, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: If he were living, I would try him yet.
Lend me an arm; the rest have worn me out
With several applications; nature and sickness
Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, count;
My son's no dearer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: Thank your majesty.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: I will now hear; what say you of this gentlewoman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Steward
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, the care I have had to even your content, I
wish might be found in the calendar of my past
endeavours; for then we wound our modesty and make
foul the clearness of our deservings, when of
ourselves we publish them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: What does this knave here? Get you gone, sirrah:
the complaints I have heard of you I do not all
believe: 'tis my slowness that I do not; for I know
you lack not folly to commit them, and have ability
enough to make such knaveries yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: No, madam, 'tis not so well that I am poor, though
many of the rich are damned: but, if I may have
your ladyship's good will to go to the world, Isbel
the woman and I will do as we may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: I do beg your good will in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: In what case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: In Isbel's case and mine own. Service is no
heritage: and I think I shall never have the
blessing of God till I have issue o' my body; for
they say barnes are blessings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: My poor body, madam, requires it: I am driven on
by the flesh; and he must needs go that the devil drives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Is this all your worship's reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons such as they
are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: May the world know them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you and
all flesh and blood are; and, indeed, I do marry
that I may repent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Thy marriage, sooner than thy wickedness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: I am out o' friends, madam; and I hope to have
friends for my wife's sake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: You're shallow, madam, in great friends; for the
knaves come to do that for me which I am aweary of.
He that ears my land spares my team and gives me
leave to in the crop; if I be his cuckold, he's my
drudge: he that comforts my wife is the cherisher
of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh
and blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my
flesh and blood is my friend: ergo, he that kisses
my wife is my friend. If men could be contented to
be what they are, there were no fear in marriage;
for young Charbon the Puritan and old Poysam the
Papist, howsome'er their hearts are severed in
religion, their heads are both one; they may jowl
horns together, like any deer i' the herd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouthed and calumnious knave?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: A prophet I, madam; and I speak the truth the next
way:
For I the ballad will repeat,
Which men full true shall find;
Your marriage comes by destiny,
Your cuckoo sings by kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Get you gone, sir; I'll talk with you more anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Steward
SPEECH.LINE: May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come to
you: of her I am to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I would speak with her;
Helen, I mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Was this fair face the cause, quoth she,
Why the Grecians sacked Troy?
Fond done, done fond,
Was this King Priam's joy?
With that she sighed as she stood,
With that she sighed as she stood,
And gave this sentence then;
Among nine bad if one be good,
Among nine bad if one be good,
There's yet one good in ten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: What, one good in ten? you corrupt the song, sirrah.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: One good woman in ten, madam; which is a purifying
o' the song: would God would serve the world so all
the year! we'ld find no fault with the tithe-woman,
if I were the parson. One in ten, quoth a'! An we
might have a good woman born but one every blazing
star, or at an earthquake, 'twould mend the lottery
well: a man may draw his heart out, ere a' pluck
one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: You'll be gone, sir knave, and do as I command you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: That man should be at woman's command, and yet no
hurt done! Though honesty be no puritan, yet it
will do no hurt; it will wear the surplice of
humility over the black gown of a big heart. I am
going, forsooth: the business is for Helen to come hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Steward
SPEECH.LINE: I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman entirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, I do: her father bequeathed her to me; and
she herself, without other advantage, may lawfully
make title to as much love as she finds: there is
more owing her than is paid; and more shall be paid
her than she'll demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Steward
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I was very late more near her than I think
she wished me: alone she was, and did communicate
to herself her own words to her own ears; she
thought, I dare vow for her, they touched not any
stranger sense. Her matter was, she loved your son:
Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that had put
such difference betwixt their two estates; Love no
god, that would not extend his might, only where
qualities were level; Dian no queen of virgins, that
would suffer her poor knight surprised, without
rescue in the first assault or ransom afterward.
This she delivered in the most bitter touch of
sorrow that e'er I heard virgin exclaim in: which I
held my duty speedily to acquaint you withal;
sithence, in the loss that may happen, it concerns
you something to know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: You have discharged this honestly; keep it to
yourself: many likelihoods informed me of this
before, which hung so tottering in the balance that
I could neither believe nor misdoubt. Pray you,
leave me: stall this in your bosom; and I thank you
for your honest care: I will speak with you further anon.
Even so it was with me when I was young:
If ever we are nature's, these are ours; this thorn
Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong;
Our blood to us, this to our blood is born;
It is the show and seal of nature's truth,
Where love's strong passion is impress'd in youth:
By our remembrances of days foregone,
Such were our faults, or then we thought them none.
Her eye is sick on't: I observe her now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: What is your pleasure, madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: You know, Helen,
I am a mother to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Mine honourable mistress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, a mother:
Why not a mother? When I said 'a mother,'
Methought you saw a serpent: what's in 'mother,'
That you start at it? I say, I am your mother;
And put you in the catalogue of those
That were enwombed mine: 'tis often seen
Adoption strives with nature and choice breeds
A native slip to us from foreign seeds:
You ne'er oppress'd me with a mother's groan,
Yet I express to you a mother's care:
God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blood
To say I am thy mother? What's the matter,
That this distemper'd messenger of wet,
The many-colour'd Iris, rounds thine eye?
Why? that you are my daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: That I am not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: I say, I am your mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, madam;
The Count Rousillon cannot be my brother:
I am from humble, he from honour'd name;
No note upon my parents, his all noble:
My master, my dear lord he is; and I
His servant live, and will his vassal die:
He must not be my brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I your mother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: You are my mother, madam; would you were,--
So that my lord your son were not my brother,--
Indeed my mother! or were you both our mothers,
I care no more for than I do for heaven,
So I were not his sister. Can't no other,
But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law:
God shield you mean it not! daughter and mother
So strive upon your pulse. What, pale again?
My fear hath catch'd your fondness: now I see
The mystery of your loneliness, and find
Your salt tears' head: now to all sense 'tis gross
You love my son; invention is ashamed,
Against the proclamation of thy passion,
To say thou dost not: therefore tell me true;
But tell me then, 'tis so; for, look thy cheeks
Confess it, th' one to th' other; and thine eyes
See it so grossly shown in thy behaviors
That in their kind they speak it: only sin
And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue,
That truth should be suspected. Speak, is't so?
If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew;
If it be not, forswear't: howe'er, I charge thee,
As heaven shall work in me for thine avail,
Tell me truly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Good madam, pardon me!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Do you love my son?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Your pardon, noble mistress!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Love you my son?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Do not you love him, madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Go not about; my love hath in't a bond,
Whereof the world takes note: come, come, disclose
The state of your affection; for your passions
Have to the full appeach'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Then, I confess,
Here on my knee, before high heaven and you,
That before you, and next unto high heaven,
I love your son.
My friends were poor, but honest; so's my love:
Be not offended; for it hurts not him
That he is loved of me: I follow him not
By any token of presumptuous suit;
Nor would I have him till I do deserve him;
Yet never know how that desert should be.
I know I love in vain, strive against hope;
Yet in this captious and intenible sieve
I still pour in the waters of my love
And lack not to lose still: thus, Indian-like,
Religious in mine error, I adore
The sun, that looks upon his worshipper,
But knows of him no more. My dearest madam,
Let not your hate encounter with my love
For loving where you do: but if yourself,
Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth,
Did ever in so true a flame of liking
Wish chastely and love dearly, that your Dian
Was both herself and love: O, then, give pity
To her, whose state is such that cannot choose
But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
That seeks not to find that her search implies,
But riddle-like lives sweetly where she dies!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Had you not lately an intent,--speak truly,--
To go to Paris?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore? tell true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear.
You know my father left me some prescriptions
Of rare and proved effects, such as his reading
And manifest experience had collected
For general sovereignty; and that he will'd me
In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them,
As notes whose faculties inclusive were
More than they were in note: amongst the rest,
There is a remedy, approved, set down,
To cure the desperate languishings whereof
The king is render'd lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: This was your motive
For Paris, was it? speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: My lord your son made me to think of this;
Else Paris and the medicine and the king
Had from the conversation of my thoughts
Haply been absent then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: But think you, Helen,
If you should tender your supposed aid,
He would receive it? he and his physicians
Are of a mind; he, that they cannot help him,
They, that they cannot help: how shall they credit
A poor unlearned virgin, when the schools,
Embowell'd of their doctrine, have left off
The danger to itself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: There's something in't,
More than my father's skill, which was the greatest
Of his profession, that his good receipt
Shall for my legacy be sanctified
By the luckiest stars in heaven: and, would your honour
But give me leave to try success, I'ld venture
The well-lost life of mine on his grace's cure
By such a day and hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou believe't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, madam, knowingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love,
Means and attendants and my loving greetings
To those of mine in court: I'll stay at home
And pray God's blessing into thy attempt:
Be gone to-morrow; and be sure of this,
What I can help thee to thou shalt not miss.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, young lords; these warlike principles
Do not throw from you: and you, my lords, farewell:
Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain, all
The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis received,
And is enough for both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis our hope, sir,
After well enter'd soldiers, to return
And find your grace in health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart
Will not confess he owes the malady
That doth my life besiege. Farewell, young lords;
Whether I live or die, be you the sons
Of worthy Frenchmen: let higher Italy,--
Those bated that inherit but the fall
Of the last monarchy,--see that you come
Not to woo honour, but to wed it; when
The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek,
That fame may cry you loud: I say, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Lord
SPEECH.LINE: Health, at your bidding, serve your majesty!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Those girls of Italy, take heed of them:
They say, our French lack language to deny,
If they demand: beware of being captives,
Before you serve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: Our hearts receive your warnings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell. Come hither to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: O, my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis not his fault, the spark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Lord
SPEECH.LINE: O, 'tis brave wars!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Most admirable: I have seen those wars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: I am commanded here, and kept a coil with
'Too young' and 'the next year' and ''tis too early.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: An thy mind stand to't, boy, steal away bravely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock,
Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry,
Till honour be bought up and no sword worn
But one to dance with! By heaven, I'll steal away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: There's honour in the theft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Commit it, count.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Lord
SPEECH.LINE: I am your accessary; and so, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: I grow to you, and our parting is a tortured body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, captain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Lord
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Monsieur Parolles!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin. Good
sparks and lustrous, a word, good metals: you shall
find in the regiment of the Spinii one Captain
Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of war, here
on his sinister cheek; it was this very sword
entrenched it: say to him, I live; and observe his
reports for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: We shall, noble captain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Mars dote on you for his novices! what will ye do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: Stay: the king.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter KING. BERTRAM and PAROLLES retire

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: To BERTRAM Use a more spacious ceremony to the
noble lords; you have restrained yourself within the
list of too cold an adieu: be more expressive to
them: for they wear themselves in the cap of the
time, there do muster true gait, eat, speak, and
move under the influence of the most received star;
and though the devil lead the measure, such are to
be followed: after them, and take a more dilated farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: And I will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy fellows; and like to prove most sinewy sword-men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Kneeling Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: I'll fee thee to stand up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Then here's a man stands, that has brought his pardon.
I would you had kneel'd, my lord, to ask me mercy,
And that at my bidding you could so stand up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had; so I had broke thy pate,
And ask'd thee mercy for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Good faith, across: but, my good lord 'tis thus;
Will you be cured of your infirmity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: O, will you eat no grapes, my royal fox?
Yes, but you will my noble grapes, an if
My royal fox could reach them: I have seen a medicine
That's able to breathe life into a stone,
Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary
With spritely fire and motion; whose simple touch,
Is powerful to araise King Pepin, nay,
To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand,
And write to her a love-line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: What 'her' is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Doctor She: my lord, there's one arrived,
If you will see her: now, by my faith and honour,
If seriously I may convey my thoughts
In this my light deliverance, I have spoke
With one that, in her sex, her years, profession,
Wisdom and constancy, hath amazed me more
Than I dare blame my weakness: will you see her
For that is her demand, and know her business?
That done, laugh well at me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Now, good Lafeu,
Bring in the admiration; that we with thee
May spend our wonder too, or take off thine
By wondering how thou took'st it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I'll fit you,
And not be all day neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, come your ways.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: This haste hath wings indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, come your ways:
This is his majesty; say your mind to him:
A traitor you do look like; but such traitors
His majesty seldom fears: I am Cressid's uncle,
That dare leave two together; fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Now, fair one, does your business follow us?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my good lord.
Gerard de Narbon was my father;
In what he did profess, well found.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: I knew him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: The rather will I spare my praises towards him:
Knowing him is enough. On's bed of death
Many receipts he gave me: chiefly one.
Which, as the dearest issue of his practise,
And of his old experience the oily darling,
He bade me store up, as a triple eye,
Safer than mine own two, more dear; I have so;
And hearing your high majesty is touch'd
With that malignant cause wherein the honour
Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power,
I come to tender it and my appliance
With all bound humbleness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: We thank you, maiden;
But may not be so credulous of cure,
When our most learned doctors leave us and
The congregated college have concluded
That labouring art can never ransom nature
From her inaidible estate; I say we must not
So stain our judgment, or corrupt our hope,
To prostitute our past-cure malady
To empirics, or to dissever so
Our great self and our credit, to esteem
A senseless help when help past sense we deem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: My duty then shall pay me for my pains:
I will no more enforce mine office on you.
Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts
A modest one, to bear me back a again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot give thee less, to be call'd grateful:
Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give
As one near death to those that wish him live:
But what at full I know, thou know'st no part,
I knowing all my peril, thou no art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: What I can do can do no hurt to try,
Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy.
He that of greatest works is finisher
Oft does them by the weakest minister:
So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown,
When judges have been babes; great floods have flown
From simple sources, and great seas have dried
When miracles have by the greatest been denied.
Oft expectation fails and most oft there
Where most it promises, and oft it hits
Where hope is coldest and despair most fits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: I must not hear thee; fare thee well, kind maid;
Thy pains not used must by thyself be paid:
Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd:
It is not so with Him that all things knows
As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows;
But most it is presumption in us when
The help of heaven we count the act of men.
Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent;
Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
I am not an impostor that proclaim
Myself against the level of mine aim;
But know I think and think I know most sure
My art is not past power nor you past cure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Are thou so confident? within what space
Hopest thou my cure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: The great'st grace lending grace
Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring,
Ere twice in murk and occidental damp
Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sleepy lamp,
Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass
Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass,
What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly,
Health shall live free and sickness freely die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Upon thy certainty and confidence
What darest thou venture?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Tax of impudence,
A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame
Traduced by odious ballads: my maiden's name
Sear'd otherwise; nay, worse--if worse--extended
With vilest torture let my life be ended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
His powerful sound within an organ weak:
And what impossibility would slay
In common sense, sense saves another way.
Thy life is dear; for all that life can rate
Worth name of life in thee hath estimate,
Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all
That happiness and prime can happy call:
Thou this to hazard needs must intimate
Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.
Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try,
That ministers thine own death if I die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: If I break time, or flinch in property
Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die,
And well deserved: not helping, death's my fee;
But, if I help, what do you promise me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Make thy demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: But will you make it even?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand
What husband in thy power I will command:
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To choose from forth the royal blood of France,
My low and humble name to propagate
With any branch or image of thy state;
But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know
Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Here is my hand; the premises observed,
Thy will by my performance shall be served:
So make the choice of thy own time, for I,
Thy resolved patient, on thee still rely.
More should I question thee, and more I must,
Though more to know could not be more to trust,
From whence thou camest, how tended on: but rest
Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest.
Give me some help here, ho! If thou proceed
As high as word, my deed shall match thy meed.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, sir; I shall now put you to the height of
your breeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught: I
know my business is but to the court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: To the court! why, what place make you special,
when you put off that with such contempt? But to the court!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners, he
may easily put it off at court: he that cannot make
a leg, put off's cap, kiss his hand and say nothing,
has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap; and indeed
such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the
court; but for me, I have an answer will serve all
men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, that's a bountiful answer that fits all
questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: It is like a barber's chair that fits all buttocks,
the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock, the brawn
buttock, or any buttock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Will your answer serve fit to all questions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney,
as your French crown for your taffeta punk, as Tib's
rush for Tom's forefinger, as a pancake for Shrove
Tuesday, a morris for May-day, as the nail to his
hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding queen
to a wrangling knave, as the nun's lip to the
friar's mouth, nay, as the pudding to his skin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness for all
questions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: From below your duke to beneath your constable, it
will fit any question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: It must be an answer of most monstrous size that
must fit all demands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned
should speak truth of it: here it is, and all that
belongs to't. Ask me if I am a courtier: it shall
do you no harm to learn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: To be young again, if we could: I will be a fool in
question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. I
pray you, sir, are you a courtier?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, sir! There's a simple putting off. More,
more, a hundred of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, sir! Thick, thick, spare not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely meat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, sir! Nay, put me to't, I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: You were lately whipped, sir, as I think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, sir! spare not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Do you cry, 'O Lord, sir!' at your whipping, and
'spare not me?' Indeed your 'O Lord, sir!' is very
sequent to your whipping: you would answer very well
to a whipping, if you were but bound to't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my 'O Lord,
sir!' I see things may serve long, but not serve ever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: I play the noble housewife with the time
To entertain't so merrily with a fool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, sir! why, there't serves well again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: An end, sir; to your business. Give Helen this,
And urge her to a present answer back:
Commend me to my kinsmen and my son:
This is not much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Not much commendation to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Not much employment for you: you understand me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
SPEECH.LINE: Most fruitfully: I am there before my legs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS
SPEECH.LINE: Haste you again.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: They say miracles are past; and we have our
philosophical persons, to make modern and familiar,
things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it that
we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves
into seeming knowledge, when we should submit
ourselves to an unknown fear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath
shot out in our latter times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: And so 'tis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: To be relinquish'd of the artists,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: So I say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Both of Galen and Paracelsus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: So I say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Of all the learned and authentic fellows,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Right; so I say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: That gave him out incurable,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Why, there 'tis; so say I too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Not to be helped,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Right; as 'twere, a man assured of a--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Uncertain life, and sure death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Just, you say well; so would I have said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: It is, indeed: if you will have it in showing, you
shall read it in--what do you call there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: That's it; I would have said the very same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Why, your dolphin is not lustier: 'fore me,
I speak in respect--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange, that is the
brief and the tedious of it; and he's of a most
facinerious spirit that will not acknowledge it to be the--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Very hand of heaven.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, so I say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: In a most weak--
and debile minister, great power, great
transcendence: which should, indeed, give us a
further use to be made than alone the recovery of
the king, as to be--
generally thankful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: I would have said it; you say well. Here comes the king.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Lustig, as the Dutchman says: I'll like a maid the
better, whilst I have a tooth in my head: why, he's
able to lead her a coranto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Mort du vinaigre! is not this Helen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: 'Fore God, I think so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Go, call before me all the lords in court.
Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side;
And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense
Thou hast repeal'd, a second time receive
The confirmation of my promised gift,
Which but attends thy naming.
Fair maid, send forth thine eye: this youthful parcel
Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing,
O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice
I have to use: thy frank election make;
Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress
Fall, when Love please! marry, to each, but one!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: I'ld give bay Curtal and his furniture,
My mouth no more were broken than these boys',
And writ as little beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Peruse them well:
Not one of those but had a noble father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen,
Heaven hath through me restored the king to health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest,
That I protest I simply am a maid.
Please it your majesty, I have done already:
The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me,
'We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused,
Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever;
We'll ne'er come there again.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Make choice; and, see,
Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly,
And to imperial Love, that god most high,
Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Lord
SPEECH.LINE: And grant it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-ace
for my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes,
Before I speak, too threateningly replies:
Love make your fortunes twenty times above
Her that so wishes and her humble love!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Lord
SPEECH.LINE: No better, if you please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: My wish receive,
Which great Love grant! and so, I take my leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine,
I'd have them whipped; or I would send them to the
Turk, to make eunuchs of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: Be not afraid that I your hand should take;
I'll never do you wrong for your own sake:
Blessing upon your vows! and in your bed
Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: These boys are boys of ice, they'll none have her:
sure, they are bastards to the English; the French
ne'er got 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: You are too young, too happy, and too good,
To make yourself a son out of my blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Lord
SPEECH.LINE: Fair one, I think not so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: There's one grape yet; I am sure thy father drunk
wine: but if thou be'st not an ass, I am a youth
of fourteen; I have known thee already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: To BERTRAM I dare not say I take you; but I give
Me and my service, ever whilst I live,
Into your guiding power. This is the man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness,
In such a business give me leave to use
The help of mine own eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Know'st thou not, Bertram,
What she has done for me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, my good lord;
But never hope to know why I should marry her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Thou know'st she has raised me from my sickly bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down
Must answer for your raising? I know her well:
She had her breeding at my father's charge.
A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain
Rather corrupt me ever!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which
I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods,
Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd all together,
Would quite confound distinction, yet stand off
In differences so mighty. If she be
All that is virtuous, save what thou dislikest,
A poor physician's daughter, thou dislikest
Of virtue for the name: but do not so:
From lowest place when virtuous things proceed,
The place is dignified by the doer's deed:
Where great additions swell's, and virtue none,
It is a dropsied honour. Good alone
Is good without a name. Vileness is so:
The property by what it is should go,
Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair;
In these to nature she's immediate heir,
And these breed honour: that is honour's scorn,
Which challenges itself as honour's born
And is not like the sire: honours thrive,
When rather from our acts we them derive
Than our foregoers: the mere word's a slave
Debosh'd on every tomb, on every grave
A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb
Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb
Of honour'd bones indeed. What should be said?
If thou canst like this creature as a maid,
I can create the rest: virtue and she
Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELENA
SPEECH.LINE: That you are well restored, my lord, I'm glad:
Let the rest go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: My honour's at the stake; which to defeat,
I must produce my power. Here, take her hand,
Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift;
That dost in vile misprision shackle up
My love and her desert; that canst not dream,
We, poising us in her defective scale,
Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know,
It is in us to plant thine honour where
We please to have it grow. Cheque thy contempt:
Obey our will, which travails in thy good:
Believe not thy disdain, but presently
Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
Which both thy duty owes and our power claims;
Or I will throw thee from my care for ever
Into the staggers and the careless lapse
Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate
Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice,
Without all terms of pity. Speak; thine answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit
My fancy to your eyes: when I consider
What great creation and what dole of honour
Flies where you bid it, I find that she, which late
Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now
The praised of the king; who, so ennobled,
Is as 'twere born so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Take her by the hand,
And tell her she is thine: to whom I promise
A counterpoise, if not to thy estate
A balance more replete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BERTRAM
SPEECH.LINE: I take her hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING
SPEECH.LINE: Good fortune and the favour of the king
Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony
Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief,
And be perform'd to-night: the solemn feast
Shall more attend upon the coming space,
Expecting absent friends. As thou lovest her,
Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Advancing Do you hear, monsieur? a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Your pleasure, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Your lord and master did well to make his
recantation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: Recantation! My lord! my master!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Ay; is it not a language I speak?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
SPEECH.LINE: A most harsh one, and not to be understood without
bloody succeeding. My master!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAFEU
SPEECH.LINE: Are you companion to the Count Rousillon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAROLLES
