Good duke, receive thy daughter
Hymen from heaven brought her,
Yea, brought her hither,
That thou mightst join her hand with his
Whose heart within his bosom is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROSALIND
SPEECH.LINE: To DUKE SENIOR To you I give myself, for I am yours.
To you I give myself, for I am yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SENIOR
SPEECH.LINE: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ORLANDO
SPEECH.LINE: If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PHEBE
SPEECH.LINE: If sight and shape be true,
Why then, my love adieu!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROSALIND
SPEECH.LINE: I'll have no father, if you be not he:
I'll have no husband, if you be not he:
Nor ne'er wed woman, if you be not she.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HYMEN
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, ho! I bar confusion:
'Tis I must make conclusion
Of these most strange events:
Here's eight that must take hands
To join in Hymen's bands,
If truth holds true contents.
You and you no cross shall part:
You and you are heart in heart
You to his love must accord,
Or have a woman to your lord:
You and you are sure together,
As the winter to foul weather.
Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing,
Feed yourselves with questioning;
That reason wonder may diminish,
How thus we met, and these things finish.
Wedding is great Juno's crown:
O blessed bond of board and bed!
'Tis Hymen peoples every town;
High wedlock then be honoured:
Honour, high honour and renown,
To Hymen, god of every town!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SENIOR
SPEECH.LINE: O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me!
Even daughter, welcome, in no less degree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PHEBE
SPEECH.LINE: I will not eat my word, now thou art mine;
Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JAQUES DE BOYS
SPEECH.LINE: Let me have audience for a word or two:
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,
That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day
Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
Address'd a mighty power; which were on foot,
In his own conduct, purposely to take
His brother here and put him to the sword:
And to the skirts of this wild wood he came;
Where meeting with an old religious man,
After some question with him, was converted
Both from his enterprise and from the world,
His crown bequeathing to his banish'd brother,
And all their lands restored to them again
That were with him exiled. This to be true,
I do engage my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SENIOR
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, young man;
Thou offer'st fairly to thy brothers' wedding:
To one his lands withheld, and to the other
A land itself at large, a potent dukedom.
First, in this forest, let us do those ends
That here were well begun and well begot:
And after, every of this happy number
That have endured shrewd days and nights with us
Shall share the good of our returned fortune,
According to the measure of their states.
Meantime, forget this new-fall'n dignity
And fall into our rustic revelry.
Play, music! And you, brides and bridegrooms all,
With measure heap'd in joy, to the measures fall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JAQUES
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, by your patience. If I heard you rightly,
The duke hath put on a religious life
And thrown into neglect the pompous court?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JAQUES DE BOYS
SPEECH.LINE: He hath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JAQUES
SPEECH.LINE: To him will I : out of these convertites
There is much matter to be heard and learn'd.
You to your former honour I bequeath;
Your patience and your virtue well deserves it:
You to a love that your true faith doth merit:
You to your land and love and great allies:
You to a long and well-deserved bed:
And you to wrangling; for thy loving voyage
Is but for two months victuall'd. So, to your pleasures:
I am for other than for dancing measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SENIOR
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, Jaques, stay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JAQUES
SPEECH.LINE: To see no pastime I what you would have
I'll stay to know at your abandon'd cave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SENIOR
SPEECH.LINE: Proceed, proceed: we will begin these rites,
As we do trust they'll end, in true delights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROSALIND
SPEECH.LINE: It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue;
but it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord
the prologue. If it be true that good wine needs
no bush, 'tis true that a good play needs no
epilogue; yet to good wine they do use good bushes,
and good plays prove the better by the help of good
epilogues. What a case am I in then, that am
neither a good epilogue nor cannot insinuate with
you in the behalf of a good play! I am not
furnished like a beggar, therefore to beg will not
become me: my way is to conjure you; and I'll begin
with the women. I charge you, O women, for the love
you bear to men, to like as much of this play as
please you: and I charge you, O men, for the love
you bear to women--as I perceive by your simpering,
none of you hates them--that between you and the
women the play may please. If I were a woman I
would kiss as many of you as had beards that pleased
me, complexions that liked me and breaths that I
defied not: and, I am sure, as many as have good
beards or good faces or sweet breaths will, for my
kind offer, when I make curtsy, bid me farewell.

PERSONAE.TITLE: Dramatis Personae

PGROUP.GRPDESCR: twin brothers, and sons to Aegeon and Aemilia.
twin brothers, and attendants on the two Antipholuses.

PERSONAE.PERSONA: First Merchant, friend to Antipholus of Syracuse.
Second Merchant, to whom Angelo is a debtor.
AEMILIA, wife to Aegeon, an abbess at Ephesus.
ADRIANA, wife to Antipholus of Ephesus.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, AEGEON, Gaoler, Officers, and other Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall
And by the doom of death end woes and all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more;
I am not partial to infringe our laws:
The enmity and discord which of late
Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke
To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen,
Who wanting guilders to redeem their lives
Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods,
Excludes all pity from our threatening looks.
For, since the mortal and intestine jars
'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us,
It hath in solemn synods been decreed
Both by the Syracusians and ourselves,
To admit no traffic to our adverse towns Nay, more,
If any born at Ephesus be seen
At any Syracusian marts and fairs;
Again: if any Syracusian born
Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies,
His goods confiscate to the duke's dispose,
Unless a thousand marks be levied,
To quit the penalty and to ransom him.
Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,
Cannot amount unto a hundred marks;
Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Yet this my comfort: when your words are done,
My woes end likewise with the evening sun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause
Why thou departed'st from thy native home
And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: A heavier task could not have been imposed
Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable:
Yet, that the world may witness that my end
Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,
I'll utter what my sorrows give me leave.
In Syracusa was I born, and wed
Unto a woman, happy but for me,
And by me, had not our hap been bad.
With her I lived in joy; our wealth increased
By prosperous voyages I often made
To Epidamnum; till my factor's death
And the great care of goods at random left
Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse:
From whom my absence was not six months old
Before herself, almost at fainting under
The pleasing punishment that women bear,
Had made provision for her following me
And soon and safe arrived where I was.
There had she not been long, but she became
A joyful mother of two goodly sons;
And, which was strange, the one so like the other,
As could not be distinguish'd but by names.
That very hour, and in the self-same inn,
A meaner woman was delivered
Of such a burden, male twins, both alike:
Those,--for their parents were exceeding poor,--
I bought and brought up to attend my sons.
My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys,
Made daily motions for our home return:
Unwilling I agreed. Alas! too soon,
We came aboard.
A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd,
Before the always wind-obeying deep
Gave any tragic instance of our harm:
But longer did we not retain much hope;
For what obscured light the heavens did grant
Did but convey unto our fearful minds
A doubtful warrant of immediate death;
Which though myself would gladly have embraced,
Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,
Weeping before for what she saw must come,
And piteous plainings of the pretty babes,
That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to fear,
Forced me to seek delays for them and me.
And this it was, for other means was none:
The sailors sought for safety by our boat,
And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us:
My wife, more careful for the latter-born,
Had fasten'd him unto a small spare mast,
Such as seafaring men provide for storms;
To him one of the other twins was bound,
Whilst I had been like heedful of the other:
The children thus disposed, my wife and I,
Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd,
Fasten'd ourselves at either end the mast;
And floating straight, obedient to the stream,
Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.
At length the sun, gazing upon the earth,
Dispersed those vapours that offended us;
And by the benefit of his wished light,
The seas wax'd calm, and we discovered
Two ships from far making amain to us,
Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this:
But ere they came,--O, let me say no more!
Gather the sequel by that went before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, forward, old man; do not break off so;
For we may pity, though not pardon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: O, had the gods done so, I had not now
Worthily term'd them merciless to us!
For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues,
We were encounterd by a mighty rock;
Which being violently borne upon,
Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst;
So that, in this unjust divorce of us,
Fortune had left to both of us alike
What to delight in, what to sorrow for.
Her part, poor soul! seeming as burdened
With lesser weight but not with lesser woe,
Was carried with more speed before the wind;
And in our sight they three were taken up
By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.
At length, another ship had seized on us;
And, knowing whom it was their hap to save,
Gave healthful welcome to their shipwreck'd guests;
And would have reft the fishers of their prey,
Had not their bark been very slow of sail;
And therefore homeward did they bend their course.
Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss;
That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd,
To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,
Do me the favour to dilate at full
What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care,
At eighteen years became inquisitive
After his brother: and importuned me
That his attendant--so his case was like,
Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name--
Might bear him company in the quest of him:
Whom whilst I labour'd of a love to see,
I hazarded the loss of whom I loved.
Five summers have I spent in furthest Greece,
Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia,
And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus;
Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought
Or that or any place that harbours men.
But here must end the story of my life;
And happy were I in my timely death,
Could all my travels warrant me they live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hapless AEgeon, whom the fates have mark'd
To bear the extremity of dire mishap!
Now, trust me, were it not against our laws,
Against my crown, my oath, my dignity,
Which princes, would they, may not disannul,
My soul would sue as advocate for thee.
But, though thou art adjudged to the death
And passed sentence may not be recall'd
But to our honour's great disparagement,
Yet I will favour thee in what I can.
Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day
To seek thy life by beneficial help:
Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;
Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum,
And live; if no, then thou art doom'd to die.
Gaoler, take him to thy custody.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gaoler
SPEECH.LINE: I will, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Hopeless and helpless doth AEgeon wend,
But to procrastinate his lifeless end.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The Mart.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse, DROMIO of Syracuse, and First Merchant

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum,
Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.
This very day a Syracusian merchant
Is apprehended for arrival here;
And not being able to buy out his life
According to the statute of the town,
Dies ere the weary sun set in the west.
There is your money that I had to keep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host,
And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.
Within this hour it will be dinner-time:
Till that, I'll view the manners of the town,
Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings,
And then return and sleep within mine inn,
For with long travel I am stiff and weary.
Get thee away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Many a man would take you at your word,
And go indeed, having so good a mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: A trusty villain, sir, that very oft,
When I am dull with care and melancholy,
Lightens my humour with his merry jests.
What, will you walk with me about the town,
And then go to my inn and dine with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: I am invited, sir, to certain merchants,
Of whom I hope to make much benefit;
I crave your pardon. Soon at five o'clock,
Please you, I'll meet with you upon the mart
And afterward consort you till bed-time:
My present business calls me from you now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell till then: I will go lose myself
And wander up and down to view the city.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I commend you to your own content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: He that commends me to mine own content
Commends me to the thing I cannot get.
I to the world am like a drop of water
That in the ocean seeks another drop,
Who, falling there to find his fellow forth,
Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself:
So I, to find a mother and a brother,
In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself.
Here comes the almanac of my true date.
What now? how chance thou art return'd so soon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Return'd so soon! rather approach'd too late:
The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit,
The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell;
My mistress made it one upon my cheek:
She is so hot because the meat is cold;
The meat is cold because you come not home;
You come not home because you have no stomach;
You have no stomach having broke your fast;
But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray
Are penitent for your default to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Stop in your wind, sir: tell me this, I pray:
Where have you left the money that I gave you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: O,--sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last
To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?
The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I am not in a sportive humour now:
Tell me, and dally not, where is the money?
We being strangers here, how darest thou trust
So great a charge from thine own custody?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you, air, as you sit at dinner:
I from my mistress come to you in post;
If I return, I shall be post indeed,
For she will score your fault upon my pate.
Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock,
And strike you home without a messenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season;
Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.
Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: To me, sir? why, you gave no gold to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness,
And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart
Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner:
My mistress and her sister stays for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: In what safe place you have bestow'd my money,
Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours
That stands on tricks when I am undisposed:
Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I have some marks of yours upon my pate,
Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders,
But not a thousand marks between you both.
If I should pay your worship those again,
Perchance you will not bear them patiently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Thy mistress' marks? what mistress, slave, hast thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Your worship's wife, my mistress at the Phoenix;
She that doth fast till you come home to dinner,
And prays that you will hie you home to dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face,
Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: What mean you, sir? for God's sake, hold your hands!
Nay, and you will not, sir, I'll take my heels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Upon my life, by some device or other
The villain is o'er-raught of all my money.
They say this town is full of cozenage,
As, nimble jugglers that deceive the eye,
Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind,
Soul-killing witches that deform the body,
Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks,
And many such-like liberties of sin:
If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner.
I'll to the Centaur, to go seek this slave:
I greatly fear my money is not safe.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Neither my husband nor the slave return'd,
That in such haste I sent to seek his master!
Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Perhaps some merchant hath invited him,
And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner.
Good sister, let us dine and never fret:
A man is master of his liberty:
Time is their master, and, when they see time,
They'll go or come: if so, be patient, sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Why should their liberty than ours be more?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Because their business still lies out o' door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Look, when I serve him so, he takes it ill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: O, know he is the bridle of your will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: There's none but asses will be bridled so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, headstrong liberty is lash'd with woe.
There's nothing situate under heaven's eye
But hath his bound, in earth, in sea, in sky:
The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls,
Are their males' subjects and at their controls:
Men, more divine, the masters of all these,
Lords of the wide world and wild watery seas,
Indued with intellectual sense and souls,
Of more preeminence than fish and fowls,
Are masters to their females, and their lords:
Then let your will attend on their accords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: This servitude makes you to keep unwed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Not this, but troubles of the marriage-bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ere I learn love, I'll practise to obey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: How if your husband start some other where?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Till he come home again, I would forbear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Patience unmoved! no marvel though she pause;
They can be meek that have no other cause.
A wretched soul, bruised with adversity,
We bid be quiet when we hear it cry;
But were we burdened with like weight of pain,
As much or more would we ourselves complain:
So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee,
With urging helpless patience wouldst relieve me,
But, if thou live to see like right bereft,
This fool-begg'd patience in thee will be left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will marry one day, but to try.
Here comes your man; now is your husband nigh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Say, is your tardy master now at hand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two ears
can witness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Say, didst thou speak with him? know'st thou his mind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear:
Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Spake he so doubtfully, thou couldst not feel his meaning?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, he struck so plainly, I could too well feel his
blows; and withal so doubtfully that I could scarce
understand them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: But say, I prithee, is he coming home? It seems he
hath great care to please his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, mistress, sure my master is horn-mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Horn-mad, thou villain!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I mean not cuckold-mad;
But, sure, he is stark mad.
When I desired him to come home to dinner,
He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold:
''Tis dinner-time,' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he;
'Your meat doth burn,' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he:
'Will you come home?' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he.
'Where is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?'
'The pig,' quoth I, 'is burn'd;' 'My gold!' quoth he:
'My mistress, sir' quoth I; 'Hang up thy mistress!
I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Quoth who?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Quoth my master:
'I know,' quoth he, 'no house, no wife, no mistress.'
So that my errand, due unto my tongue,
I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders;
For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go back again, and be new beaten home?
For God's sake, send some other messenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And he will bless that cross with other beating:
Between you I shall have a holy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Hence, prating peasant! fetch thy master home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Am I so round with you as you with me,
That like a football you do spurn me thus?
You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither:
If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, how impatience loureth in your face!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: His company must do his minions grace,
Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.
Hath homely age the alluring beauty took
From my poor cheek? then he hath wasted it:
Are my discourses dull? barren my wit?
If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd,
Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard:
Do their gay vestments his affections bait?
That's not my fault: he's master of my state:
What ruins are in me that can be found,
By him not ruin'd? then is he the ground
Of my defeatures. My decayed fair
A sunny look of his would soon repair
But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale
And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Self-harming jealousy! fie, beat it hence!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense.
I know his eye doth homage otherwhere,
Or else what lets it but he would be here?
Sister, you know he promised me a chain;
Would that alone, alone he would detain,
So he would keep fair quarter with his bed!
I see the jewel best enamelled
Will lose his beauty; yet the gold bides still,
That others touch, and often touching will
Wear gold: and no man that hath a name,
By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.
Since that my beauty cannot please his eye,
I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. A public place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up
Safe at the Centaur; and the heedful slave
Is wander'd forth, in care to seek me out
By computation and mine host's report.
I could not speak with Dromio since at first
I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes.
How now sir! is your merry humour alter'd?
As you love strokes, so jest with me again.
You know no Centaur? you received no gold?
Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?
My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad,
That thus so madly thou didst answer me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What answer, sir? when spake I such a word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Even now, even here, not half an hour since.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I did not see you since you sent me hence,
Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Villain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt,
And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner;
For which, I hope, thou felt'st I was displeased.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to see you in this merry vein:
What means this jest? I pray you, master, tell me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?
Think'st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that, and that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Hold, sir, for God's sake! now your jest is earnest:
Upon what bargain do you give it me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Because that I familiarly sometimes
Do use you for my fool and chat with you,
Your sauciness will jest upon my love
And make a common of my serious hours.
When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport,
But creep in crannies when he hides his beams.
If you will jest with me, know my aspect,
And fashion your demeanor to my looks,
Or I will beat this method in your sconce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Sconce call you it? so you would leave battering, I
had rather have it a head: an you use these blows
long, I must get a sconce for my head and ensconce
it too; or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders.
But, I pray, sir why am I beaten?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou not know?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I tell you why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, sir, and wherefore; for they say every why hath
a wherefore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, first,--for flouting me; and then, wherefore--
For urging it the second time to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season,
When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme
nor reason?
Well, sir, I thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Thank me, sir, for what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I'll make you amends next, to give you nothing for
something. But say, sir, is it dinner-time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir; I think the meat wants that I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: In good time, sir; what's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Basting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir, then 'twill be dry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Your reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another
dry basting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir, learn to jest in good time: there's a
time for all things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I durst have denied that, before you were so choleric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: By what rule, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald
pate of father Time himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Let's hear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: There's no time for a man to recover his hair that
grows bald by nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: May he not do it by fine and recovery?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig and recover the
lost hair of another man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is,
so plentiful an excrement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts;
and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath given them in wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, but there's many a man hath more hair than wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: The plainer dealer, the sooner lost: yet he loseth
it in a kind of jollity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: For what reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: For two; and sound ones too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, not sound, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Sure ones, then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Certain ones then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Name them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: The one, to save the money that he spends in
trimming; the other, that at dinner they should not
drop in his porridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: You would all this time have proved there is no
time for all things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, and did, sir; namely, no time to recover hair
lost by nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: But your reason was not substantial, why there is no
time to recover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore
to the world's end will have bald followers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I knew 'twould be a bald conclusion:
But, soft! who wafts us yonder?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown:
Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects;
I am not Adriana nor thy wife.
The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow
That never words were music to thine ear,
That never object pleasing in thine eye,
That never touch well welcome to thy hand,
That never meat sweet-savor'd in thy taste,
Unless I spake, or look'd, or touch'd, or carved to thee.
How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it,
That thou art thus estranged from thyself?
Thyself I call it, being strange to me,
That, undividable, incorporate,
Am better than thy dear self's better part.
Ah, do not tear away thyself from me!
For know, my love, as easy mayest thou fall
A drop of water in the breaking gulf,
And take unmingled that same drop again,
Without addition or diminishing,
As take from me thyself and not me too.
How dearly would it touch me to the quick,
Shouldst thou but hear I were licentious
And that this body, consecrate to thee,
By ruffian lust should be contaminate!
Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me
And hurl the name of husband in my face
And tear the stain'd skin off my harlot-brow
And from my false hand cut the wedding-ring
And break it with a deep-divorcing vow?
I know thou canst; and therefore see thou do it.
I am possess'd with an adulterate blot;
My blood is mingled with the crime of lust:
For if we too be one and thou play false,
I do digest the poison of thy flesh,
Being strumpeted by thy contagion.
Keep then far league and truce with thy true bed;
I live unstain'd, thou undishonoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Plead you to me, fair dame? I know you not:
In Ephesus I am but two hours old,
As strange unto your town as to your talk;
Who, every word by all my wit being scann'd,
Want wit in all one word to understand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, brother! how the world is changed with you!
When were you wont to use my sister thus?
She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: By Dromio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: By me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: By thee; and this thou didst return from him,
That he did buffet thee, and, in his blows,
Denied my house for his, me for his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman?
What is the course and drift of your compact?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I, sir? I never saw her till this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Villain, thou liest; for even her very words
Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I never spake with her in all my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: How can she thus then call us by our names,
Unless it be by inspiration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: How ill agrees it with your gravity
To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave,
Abetting him to thwart me in my mood!
Be it my wrong you are from me exempt,
But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.
Come, I will fasten on this sleeve of thine:
Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine,
Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state,
Makes me with thy strength to communicate:
If aught possess thee from me, it is dross,
Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss;
Who, all for want of pruning, with intrusion
Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme:
What, was I married to her in my dream?
Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?
What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?
Until I know this sure uncertainty,
I'll entertain the offer'd fallacy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: O, for my beads! I cross me for a sinner.
This is the fairy land: O spite of spites!
We talk with goblins, owls and sprites:
If we obey them not, this will ensue,
They'll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Why pratest thou to thyself and answer'st not?
Dromio, thou drone, thou snail, thou slug, thou sot!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I am transformed, master, am I not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I think thou art in mind, and so am I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast thine own form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No, I am an ape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: If thou art changed to aught, 'tis to an ass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis true; she rides me and I long for grass.
'Tis so, I am an ass; else it could never be
But I should know her as well as she knows me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, no longer will I be a fool,
To put the finger in the eye and weep,
Whilst man and master laugh my woes to scorn.
Come, sir, to dinner. Dromio, keep the gate.
Husband, I'll dine above with you to-day
And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.
Sirrah, if any ask you for your master,
Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter.
Come, sister. Dromio, play the porter well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?
Sleeping or waking? mad or well-advised?
Known unto these, and to myself disguised!
I'll say as they say and persever so,
And in this mist at all adventures go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Master, shall I be porter at the gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, Antipholus, we dine too late.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus, DROMIO of Ephesus, ANGELO, and BALTHAZAR

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all;
My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours:
Say that I linger'd with you at your shop
To see the making of her carcanet,
And that to-morrow you will bring it home.
But here's a villain that would face me down
He met me on the mart, and that I beat him,
And charged him with a thousand marks in gold,
And that I did deny my wife and house.
Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know;
That you beat me at the mart, I have your hand to show:
If the skin were parchment, and the blows you gave were ink,
Your own handwriting would tell you what I think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I think thou art an ass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, so it doth appear
By the wrongs I suffer and the blows I bear.
I should kick, being kick'd; and, being at that pass,
You would keep from my heels and beware of an ass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: You're sad, Signior Balthazar: pray God our cheer
May answer my good will and your good welcome here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BALTHAZAR
SPEECH.LINE: I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your
welcome dear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, Signior Balthazar, either at flesh or fish,
A table full of welcome make scarce one dainty dish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BALTHAZAR
SPEECH.LINE: Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And welcome more common; for that's nothing but words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BALTHAZAR
SPEECH.LINE: Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, to a niggardly host, and more sparing guest:
But though my cates be mean, take them in good part;
Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.
But, soft! my door is lock'd. Go bid them let us in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Maud, Bridget, Marian, Cicel, Gillian, Ginn!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb,
idiot, patch!
Either get thee from the door, or sit down at the hatch.
Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou call'st
for such store,
When one is one too many? Go, get thee from the door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: What patch is made our porter? My master stays in
the street.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Let him walk from whence he came, lest he
catch cold on's feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Who talks within there? ho, open the door!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Right, sir; I'll tell you when, an you tell
me wherefore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore? for my dinner: I have not dined to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Nor to-day here you must not; come again
when you may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou that keepest me out from the house I owe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within The porter for this time, sir, and my name
is Dromio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: O villain! thou hast stolen both mine office and my name.
The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame.
If thou hadst been Dromio to-day in my place,
Thou wouldst have changed thy face for a name or thy
name for an ass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCE
SPEECH.LINE: Within What a coil is there, Dromio? who are those
at the gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let my master in, Luce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Faith, no; he comes too late;
And so tell your master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, I must laugh!
Have at you with a proverb--Shall I set in my staff?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Have at you with another; that's--When?
can you tell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within If thy name be call'd Luce--Luce, thou hast
answered him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Do you hear, you minion? you'll let us in, I hope?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCE
SPEECH.LINE: Within I thought to have asked you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within And you said no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: So, come, help: well struck! there was blow for blow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thou baggage, let me in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Can you tell for whose sake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Master, knock the door hard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Let him knock till it ache.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: You'll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCE
SPEECH.LINE: Within What needs all that, and a pair of stocks in the town?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Within Who is that at the door that keeps all
this noise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within By my troth, your town is troubled with
unruly boys.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Are you there, wife? you might have come before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Within Your wife, sir knave! go get you from the door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: If you went in pain, master, this 'knave' would go sore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Here is neither cheer, sir, nor welcome: we would
fain have either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BALTHAZAR
SPEECH.LINE: In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: They stand at the door, master; bid them welcome hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: There is something in the wind, that we cannot get in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.
Your cake there is warm within; you stand here in the cold:
It would make a man mad as a buck, to be so bought and sold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go fetch me something: I'll break ope the gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Break any breaking here, and I'll break your
knave's pate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: A man may break a word with you, sir, and words are but wind,
Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within It seems thou want'st breaking: out upon
thee, hind!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here's too much 'out upon thee!' I pray thee,
let me in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Within Ay, when fowls have no feathers and fish have no fin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I'll break in: go borrow me a crow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: A crow without feather? Master, mean you so?
For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather;
If a crow help us in, sirrah, we'll pluck a crow together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go get thee gone; fetch me an iron crow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BALTHAZAR
SPEECH.LINE: Have patience, sir; O, let it not be so!
Herein you war against your reputation
And draw within the compass of suspect
The unviolated honour of your wife.
Once this,--your long experience of her wisdom,
Her sober virtue, years and modesty,
Plead on her part some cause to you unknown:
And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse
Why at this time the doors are made against you.
Be ruled by me: depart in patience,
And let us to the Tiger all to dinner,
And about evening come yourself alone
To know the reason of this strange restraint.
If by strong hand you offer to break in
Now in the stirring passage of the day,
A vulgar comment will be made of it,
And that supposed by the common rout
Against your yet ungalled estimation
That may with foul intrusion enter in
And dwell upon your grave when you are dead;
For slander lives upon succession,
For ever housed where it gets possession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: You have prevailed: I will depart in quiet,
And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.
I know a wench of excellent discourse,
Pretty and witty; wild, and yet, too, gentle:
There will we dine. This woman that I mean,
My wife--but, I protest, without desert--
Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal:
To her will we to dinner.
Get you home
And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made:
Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine;
For there's the house: that chain will I bestow--
Be it for nothing but to spite my wife--
Upon mine hostess there: good sir, make haste.
Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me,
I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Do so. This jest shall cost me some expense.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The same.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter LUCIANA and ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: And may it be that you have quite forgot
A husband's office? shall, Antipholus.
Even in the spring of love, thy love-springs rot?
Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous?
If you did wed my sister for her wealth,
Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness:
Or if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth;
Muffle your false love with some show of blindness:
Let not my sister read it in your eye;
Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator;
Look sweet, be fair, become disloyalty;
Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger;
Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted;
Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint;
Be secret-false: what need she be acquainted?
What simple thief brags of his own attaint?
'Tis double wrong, to truant with your bed
And let her read it in thy looks at board:
Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed;
Ill deeds are doubled with an evil word.
Alas, poor women! make us but believe,
Being compact of credit, that you love us;
Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve;
We in your motion turn and you may move us.
Then, gentle brother, get you in again;
Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife:
'Tis holy sport to be a little vain,
When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet mistress--what your name is else, I know not,
Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine,--
Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not
Than our earth's wonder, more than earth divine.
Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak;
Lay open to my earthy-gross conceit,
Smother'd in errors, feeble, shallow, weak,
The folded meaning of your words' deceit.
Against my soul's pure truth why labour you
To make it wander in an unknown field?
Are you a god? would you create me new?
Transform me then, and to your power I'll yield.
But if that I am I, then well I know
Your weeping sister is no wife of mine,
Nor to her bed no homage do I owe
Far more, far more to you do I decline.
O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note,
To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears:
Sing, siren, for thyself and I will dote:
Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs,
And as a bed I'll take them and there lie,
And in that glorious supposition think
He gains by death that hath such means to die:
Let Love, being light, be drowned if she sink!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: What, are you mad, that you do reason so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Not mad, but mated; how, I do not know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: It is a fault that springeth from your eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Gaze where you should, and that will clear your sight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Why call you me love? call my sister so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Thy sister's sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: That's my sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No;
It is thyself, mine own self's better part,
Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart,
My food, my fortune and my sweet hope's aim,
My sole earth's heaven and my heaven's claim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: All this my sister is, or else should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Call thyself sister, sweet, for I am thee.
Thee will I love and with thee lead my life:
Thou hast no husband yet nor I no wife.
Give me thy hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: O, soft, air! hold you still:
I'll fetch my sister, to get her good will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, how now, Dromio! where runn'st thou so fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Do you know me, sir? am I Dromio? am I your man?
am I myself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I am an ass, I am a woman's man and besides myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, sir, besides myself, I am due to a woman; one
that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will have me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What claim lays she to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry sir, such claim as you would lay to your
horse; and she would have me as a beast: not that, I
being a beast, she would have me; but that she,
being a very beastly creature, lays claim to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What is she?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: A very reverent body; ay, such a one as a man may
not speak of without he say 'Sir-reverence.' I have
but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a
wondrous fat marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: How dost thou mean a fat marriage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, sir, she's the kitchen wench and all grease;
and I know not what use to put her to but to make a
lamp of her and run from her by her own light. I
warrant, her rags and the tallow in them will burn a
Poland winter: if she lives till doomsday,
she'll burn a week longer than the whole world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What complexion is she of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Swart, like my shoe, but her face nothing half so
clean kept: for why, she sweats; a man may go over
shoes in the grime of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: That's a fault that water will mend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flood could not do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What's her name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Nell, sir; but her name and three quarters, that's
an ell and three quarters, will not measure her from
hip to hip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Then she bears some breadth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip:
she is spherical, like a globe; I could find out
countries in her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: In what part of her body stands Ireland?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, in her buttocks: I found it out by the bogs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Where Scotland?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I found it by the barrenness; hard in the palm of the hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Where France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: In her forehead; armed and reverted, making war
against her heir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Where England?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I looked for the chalky cliffs, but I could find no
whiteness in them; but I guess it stood in her chin,
by the salt rheum that ran between France and it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Where Spain?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, I saw it not; but I felt it hot in her breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Where America, the Indies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, sir, upon her nose all o'er embellished with
rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich
aspect to the hot breath of Spain; who sent whole
armadoes of caracks to be ballast at her nose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, sir, I did not look so low. To conclude, this
drudge, or diviner, laid claim to me, call'd me
Dromio; swore I was assured to her; told me what
privy marks I had about me, as, the mark of my
shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my
left arm, that I amazed ran from her as a witch:
And, I think, if my breast had not been made of
faith and my heart of steel,
She had transform'd me to a curtal dog and made
me turn i' the wheel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Go hie thee presently, post to the road:
An if the wind blow any way from shore,
I will not harbour in this town to-night:
If any bark put forth, come to the mart,
Where I will walk till thou return to me.
If every one knows us and we know none,
'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack and be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: As from a bear a man would run for life,
So fly I from her that would be my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: There's none but witches do inhabit here;
And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence.
She that doth call me husband, even my soul
Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister,
Possess'd with such a gentle sovereign grace,
Of such enchanting presence and discourse,
Hath almost made me traitor to myself:
But, lest myself be guilty to self-wrong,
I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Master Antipholus,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, that's my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well, sir, lo, here is the chain.
I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine:
The chain unfinish'd made me stay thus long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What is your will that I shall do with this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: What please yourself, sir: I have made it for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Made it for me, sir! I bespoke it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.
Go home with it and please your wife withal;
And soon at supper-time I'll visit you
And then receive my money for the chain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you, sir, receive the money now,
For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: You are a merry man, sir: fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What I should think of this, I cannot tell:
But this I think, there's no man is so vain
That would refuse so fair an offer'd chain.
I see a man here needs not live by shifts,
When in the streets he meets such golden gifts.
I'll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay
If any ship put out, then straight away.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. A public place.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Second Merchant, ANGELO, and an Officer

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: You know since Pentecost the sum is due,
And since I have not much importuned you;
Nor now I had not, but that I am bound
To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage:
Therefore make present satisfaction,
Or I'll attach you by this officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Even just the sum that I do owe to you
Is growing to me by Antipholus,
And in the instant that I met with you
He had of me a chain: at five o'clock
I shall receive the money for the same.
Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house,
I will discharge my bond and thank you too.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus from the courtezan's

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: That labour may you save: see where he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: While I go to the goldsmith's house, go thou
And buy a rope's end: that will I bestow
Among my wife and her confederates,
For locking me out of my doors by day.
But, soft! I see the goldsmith. Get thee gone;
Buy thou a rope and bring it home to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I buy a thousand pound a year: I buy a rope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: A man is well holp up that trusts to you:
I promised your presence and the chain;
But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me.
Belike you thought our love would last too long,
If it were chain'd together, and therefore came not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Saving your merry humour, here's the note
How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat,
The fineness of the gold and chargeful fashion.
Which doth amount to three odd ducats more
Than I stand debted to this gentleman:
I pray you, see him presently discharged,
For he is bound to sea and stays but for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am not furnish'd with the present money;
Besides, I have some business in the town.
Good signior, take the stranger to my house
And with you take the chain and bid my wife
Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof:
Perchance I will be there as soon as you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Then you will bring the chain to her yourself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: No; bear it with you, lest I come not time enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir, I will. Have you the chain about you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: An if I have not, sir, I hope you have;
Or else you may return without your money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain:
Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman,
And I, to blame, have held him here too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Good Lord! you use this dalliance to excuse
Your breach of promise to the Porpentine.
I should have chid you for not bringing it,
But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: The hour steals on; I pray you, sir, dispatch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: You hear how he importunes me;--the chain!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, give it to my wife and fetch your money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you know I gave it you even now.
Either send the chain or send me by some token.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, now you run this humour out of breath,
where's the chain? I pray you, let me see it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: My business cannot brook this dalliance.
Good sir, say whether you'll answer me or no:
If not, I'll leave him to the officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I answer you! what should I answer you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: The money that you owe me for the chain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I owe you none till I receive the chain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: You know I gave it you half an hour since.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: You gave me none: you wrong me much to say so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: You wrong me more, sir, in denying it:
Consider how it stands upon my credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: I do; and charge you in the duke's name to obey me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: This touches me in reputation.
Either consent to pay this sum for me
Or I attach you by this officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Consent to pay thee that I never had!
Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou darest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Here is thy fee; arrest him, officer,
I would not spare my brother in this case,
If he should scorn me so apparently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: I do arrest you, sir: you hear the suit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear
As all the metal in your shop will answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, sir, I will have law in Ephesus,
To your notorious shame; I doubt it not.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter DROMIO of Syracuse, from the bay

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Master, there is a bark of Epidamnum
That stays but till her owner comes aboard,
And then, sir, she bears away. Our fraughtage, sir,
I have convey'd aboard; and I have bought
The oil, the balsamum and aqua-vitae.
The ship is in her trim; the merry wind
Blows fair from land: they stay for nought at all
But for their owner, master, and yourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: How now! a madman! Why, thou peevish sheep,
What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope;
And told thee to what purpose and what end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: You sent me for a rope's end as soon:
You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will debate this matter at more leisure
And teach your ears to list me with more heed.
To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight:
Give her this key, and tell her, in the desk
That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry,
There is a purse of ducats; let her send it:
Tell her I am arrested in the street
And that shall bail me; hie thee, slave, be gone!
On, officer, to prison till it come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Second Merchant, Angelo, Officer, and Antipholus of Ephesus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: To Adriana! that is where we dined,
Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband:
She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.
Thither I must, although against my will,
For servants must their masters' minds fulfil.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, Luciana, did he tempt thee so?
Mightst thou perceive austerely in his eye
That he did plead in earnest? yea or no?
Look'd he or red or pale, or sad or merrily?
What observation madest thou in this case
Of his heart's meteors tilting in his face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: First he denied you had in him no right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: He meant he did me none; the more my spite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Then swore he that he was a stranger here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: And true he swore, though yet forsworn he were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Then pleaded I for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: And what said he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: That love I begg'd for you he begg'd of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: With words that in an honest suit might move.
First he did praise my beauty, then my speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Didst speak him fair?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Have patience, I beseech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot, nor I will not, hold me still;
My tongue, though not my heart, shall have his will.
He is deformed, crooked, old and sere,
Ill-faced, worse bodied, shapeless everywhere;
Vicious, ungentle, foolish, blunt, unkind;
Stigmatical in making, worse in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Who would be jealous then of such a one?
No evil lost is wail'd when it is gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, but I think him better than I say,
And yet would herein others' eyes were worse.
Far from her nest the lapwing cries away:
My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Here! go; the desk, the purse! sweet, now, make haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: How hast thou lost thy breath?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: By running fast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Where is thy master, Dromio? is he well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No, he's in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.
A devil in an everlasting garment hath him;
One whose hard heart is button'd up with steel;
A fiend, a fury, pitiless and rough;
A wolf, nay, worse, a fellow all in buff;
A back-friend, a shoulder-clapper, one that
countermands
The passages of alleys, creeks and narrow lands;
A hound that runs counter and yet draws dryfoot well;
One that before the judgement carries poor souls to hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, man, what is the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know the matter: he is 'rested on the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: What, is he arrested? Tell me at whose suit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I know not at whose suit he is arrested well;
But he's in a suit of buff which 'rested him, that can I tell.
Will you send him, mistress, redemption, the money in his desk?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Go fetch it, sister.
This I wonder at,
That he, unknown to me, should be in debt.
Tell me, was he arrested on a band?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Not on a band, but on a stronger thing;
A chain, a chain! Do you not hear it ring?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: What, the chain?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, the bell: 'tis time that I were gone:
It was two ere I left him, and now the clock
strikes one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: The hours come back! that did I never hear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: O, yes; if any hour meet a sergeant, a' turns back for
very fear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: As if Time were in debt! how fondly dost thou reason!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Time is a very bankrupt, and owes more than he's
worth, to season.
Nay, he's a thief too: have you not heard men say
That Time comes stealing on by night and day?
If Time be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way,
Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Go, Dromio; there's the money, bear it straight;
And bring thy master home immediately.
Come, sister: I am press'd down with conceit--
Conceit, my comfort and my injury.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. A public place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: There's not a man I meet but doth salute me
As if I were their well-acquainted friend;
And every one doth call me by my name.
Some tender money to me; some invite me;
Some other give me thanks for kindnesses;
Some offer me commodities to buy:
Even now a tailor call'd me in his shop
And show'd me silks that he had bought for me,
And therewithal took measure of my body.
Sure, these are but imaginary wiles
And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Master, here's the gold you sent me for. What, have
you got the picture of old Adam new-apparelled?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What gold is this? what Adam dost thou mean?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Not that Adam that kept the Paradise but that Adam
that keeps the prison: he that goes in the calf's
skin that was killed for the Prodigal; he that came
behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you
forsake your liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I understand thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No? why, 'tis a plain case: he that went, like a
bass-viol, in a case of leather; the man, sir,
that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob
and 'rests them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed
men and gives them suits of durance; he that sets up
his rest to do more exploits with his mace than a
morris-pike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: What, thou meanest an officer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band, he that brings
any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that
thinks a man always going to bed, and says, 'God
give you good rest!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that the
bark Expedition put forth to-night; and then were
you hindered by the sergeant, to tarry for the hoy
Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for to
deliver you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: The fellow is distract, and so am I;
And here we wander in illusions:
Some blessed power deliver us from hence!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: Well met, well met, Master Antipholus.
I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now:
Is that the chain you promised me to-day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Satan, avoid! I charge thee, tempt me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Master, is this Mistress Satan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: It is the devil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, she is worse, she is the devil's dam; and here
she comes in the habit of a light wench: and thereof
comes that the wenches say 'God damn me;' that's as
much to say 'God make me a light wench.' It is
written, they appear to men like angels of light:
light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn;
ergo, light wenches will burn. Come not near her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: Your man and you are marvellous merry, sir.
Will you go with me? We'll mend our dinner here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat; or bespeak a
long spoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Dromio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with
the devil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Avoid then, fiend! what tell'st thou me of supping?
Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress:
I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner,
Or, for my diamond, the chain you promised,
And I'll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Some devils ask but the parings of one's nail,
A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin,
A nut, a cherry-stone;
But she, more covetous, would have a chain.
Master, be wise: an if you give it her,
The devil will shake her chain and fright us with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain:
I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: 'Fly pride,' says the peacock: mistress, that you know.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: Now, out of doubt Antipholus is mad,
Else would he never so demean himself.
A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats,
And for the same he promised me a chain:
Both one and other he denies me now.
The reason that I gather he is mad,
Besides this present instance of his rage,
Is a mad tale he told to-day at dinner,
Of his own doors being shut against his entrance.
Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits,
On purpose shut the doors against his way.
My way is now to hie home to his house,
And tell his wife that, being lunatic,
He rush'd into my house and took perforce
My ring away. This course I fittest choose;
For forty ducats is too much to lose.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. A street.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and the Officer

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fear me not, man; I will not break away:
I'll give thee, ere I leave thee, so much money,
To warrant thee, as I am 'rested for.
My wife is in a wayward mood to-day,
And will not lightly trust the messenger
That I should be attach'd in Ephesus,
I tell you, 'twill sound harshly in her ears.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter DROMIO of Ephesus with a rope's-end
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes my man; I think he brings the money.
How now, sir! have you that I sent you for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here's that, I warrant you, will pay them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: But where's the money?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Five hundred ducats, villain, for a rope?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: To a rope's-end, sir; and to that end am I returned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And to that end, sir, I will welcome you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Good sir, be patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, 'tis for me to be patient; I am in adversity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Good, now, hold thy tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thou whoreson, senseless villain!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel
your blows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am an ass, indeed; you may prove it by my long
ears. I have served him from the hour of my
nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his
hands for my service but blows. When I am cold, he
heats me with beating; when I am warm, he cools me
with beating; I am waked with it when I sleep;
raised with it when I sit; driven out of doors with
it when I go from home; welcomed home with it when
I return; nay, I bear it on my shoulders, as a
beggar wont her brat; and, I think when he hath
lamed me, I shall beg with it from door to door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, go along; my wife is coming yonder.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the Courtezan, and PINCH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Mistress, 'respice finem,' respect your end; or
rather, the prophecy like the parrot, 'beware the
rope's-end.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou still talk?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: How say you now? is not your husband mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: His incivility confirms no less.
Good Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer;
Establish him in his true sense again,
And I will please you what you will demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, how fiery and how sharp he looks!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PINCH
SPEECH.LINE: Give me your hand and let me feel your pulse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: There is my hand, and let it feel your ear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PINCH
SPEECH.LINE: I charge thee, Satan, housed within this man,
To yield possession to my holy prayers
And to thy state of darkness hie thee straight:
I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, doting wizard, peace! I am not mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: O, that thou wert not, poor distressed soul!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: You minion, you, are these your customers?
Did this companion with the saffron face
Revel and feast it at my house to-day,
Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut
And I denied to enter in my house?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: O husband, God doth know you dined at home;
Where would you had remain'd until this time,
Free from these slanders and this open shame!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Dined at home! Thou villain, what sayest thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Were not my doors lock'd up and I shut out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Perdie, your doors were lock'd and you shut out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And did not she herself revile me there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sans fable, she herself reviled you there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Did not her kitchen-maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Certes, she did; the kitchen-vestal scorn'd you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And did not I in rage depart from thence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: In verity you did; my bones bear witness,
That since have felt the vigour of his rage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Is't good to soothe him in these contraries?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PINCH
SPEECH.LINE: It is no shame: the fellow finds his vein,
And yielding to him humours well his frenzy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast suborn'd the goldsmith to arrest me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, I sent you money to redeem you,
By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Money by me! heart and goodwill you might;
But surely master, not a rag of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
