SPEECH.LINE: Went'st not thou to her for a purse of ducats?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: He came to me and I deliver'd it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: And I am witness with her that she did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: God and the rope-maker bear me witness
That I was sent for nothing but a rope!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PINCH
SPEECH.LINE: Mistress, both man and master is possess'd;
I know it by their pale and deadly looks:
They must be bound and laid in some dark room.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Say, wherefore didst thou lock me forth to-day?
And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And, gentle master, I received no gold;
But I confess, sir, that we were lock'd out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Dissembling villain, thou speak'st false in both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Dissembling harlot, thou art false in all;
And art confederate with a damned pack
To make a loathsome abject scorn of me:
But with these nails I'll pluck out these false eyes
That would behold in me this shameful sport.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter three or four, and offer to bind him. He strives

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: O, bind him, bind him! let him not come near me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PINCH
SPEECH.LINE: More company! The fiend is strong within him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me, poor man, how pale and wan he looks!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: What, will you murder me? Thou gaoler, thou,
I am thy prisoner: wilt thou suffer them
To make a rescue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Masters, let him go
He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PINCH
SPEECH.LINE: Go bind this man, for he is frantic too.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: They offer to bind Dromio of Ephesus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou do, thou peevish officer?
Hast thou delight to see a wretched man
Do outrage and displeasure to himself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: He is my prisoner: if I let him go,
The debt he owes will be required of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I will discharge thee ere I go from thee:
Bear me forthwith unto his creditor,
And, knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it.
Good master doctor, see him safe convey'd
Home to my house. O most unhappy day!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: O most unhappy strumpet!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Master, I am here entered in bond for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Out on thee, villain! wherefore dost thou mad me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Will you be bound for nothing? be mad, good master:
cry 'The devil!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: God help, poor souls, how idly do they talk!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Go bear him hence. Sister, go you with me.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but Adriana, Luciana, Officer and Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: Say now, whose suit is he arrested at?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: One Angelo, a goldsmith: do you know him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I know the man. What is the sum he owes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Two hundred ducats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Say, how grows it due?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Due for a chain your husband had of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: He did bespeak a chain for me, but had it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: When as your husband all in rage to-day
Came to my house and took away my ring--
The ring I saw upon his finger now--
Straight after did I meet him with a chain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: It may be so, but I did never see it.
Come, gaoler, bring me where the goldsmith is:
I long to know the truth hereof at large.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse with his rapier drawn, and DROMIO of Syracuse

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: God, for thy mercy! they are loose again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: And come with naked swords.
Let's call more help to have them bound again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Away! they'll kill us.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I see these witches are afraid of swords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: She that would be your wife now ran from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Come to the Centaur; fetch our stuff from thence:
I long that we were safe and sound aboard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, stay here this night; they will surely do us
no harm: you saw they speak us fair, give us gold:
methinks they are such a gentle nation that, but for
the mountain of mad flesh that claims marriage of
me, I could find in my heart to stay here still and
turn witch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I will not stay to-night for all the town;
Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: I am sorry, sir, that I have hinder'd you;
But, I protest, he had the chain of me,
Though most dishonestly he doth deny it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: How is the man esteemed here in the city?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Of very reverend reputation, sir,
Of credit infinite, highly beloved,
Second to none that lives here in the city:
His word might bear my wealth at any time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: Speak softly; yonder, as I think, he walks.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse and DROMIO of Syracuse

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis so; and that self chain about his neck
Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
Good sir, draw near to me, I'll speak to him.
Signior Antipholus, I wonder much
That you would put me to this shame and trouble;
And, not without some scandal to yourself,
With circumstance and oaths so to deny
This chain which now you wear so openly:
Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment,
You have done wrong to this my honest friend,
Who, but for staying on our controversy,
Had hoisted sail and put to sea to-day:
This chain you had of me; can you deny it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I think I had; I never did deny it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: These ears of mine, thou know'st did hear thee.
Fie on thee, wretch! 'tis pity that thou livest
To walk where any honest man resort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a villain to impeach me thus:
I'll prove mine honour and mine honesty
Against thee presently, if thou darest stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: I dare, and do defy thee for a villain.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the Courtezan, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Hold, hurt him not, for God's sake! he is mad.
Some get within him, take his sword away:
Bind Dromio too, and bear them to my house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Run, master, run; for God's sake, take a house!
This is some priory. In, or we are spoil'd!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse to the Priory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Be quiet, people. Wherefore throng you hither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.
Let us come in, that we may bind him fast
And bear him home for his recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: I knew he was not in his perfect wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: I am sorry now that I did draw on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: How long hath this possession held the man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad,
And much different from the man he was;
But till this afternoon his passion
Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he not lost much wealth by wreck of sea?
Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye
Stray'd his affection in unlawful love?
A sin prevailing much in youthful men,
Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing.
Which of these sorrows is he subject to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: To none of these, except it be the last;
Namely, some love that drew him oft from home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: You should for that have reprehended him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, so I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but not rough enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: As roughly as my modesty would let me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Haply, in private.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: And in assemblies too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but not enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: It was the copy of our conference:
In bed he slept not for my urging it;
At board he fed not for my urging it;
Alone, it was the subject of my theme;
In company I often glanced it;
Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: And thereof came it that the man was mad.
The venom clamours of a jealous woman
Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's tooth.
It seems his sleeps were hinder'd by thy railing,
And therefore comes it that his head is light.
Thou say'st his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings:
Unquiet meals make ill digestions;
Thereof the raging fire of fever bred;
And what's a fever but a fit of madness?
Thou say'st his sports were hinderd by thy brawls:
Sweet recreation barr'd, what doth ensue
But moody and dull melancholy,
Kinsman to grim and comfortless despair,
And at her heels a huge infectious troop
Of pale distemperatures and foes to life?
In food, in sport and life-preserving rest
To be disturb'd, would mad or man or beast:
The consequence is then thy jealous fits
Have scared thy husband from the use of wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: She never reprehended him but mildly,
When he demean'd himself rough, rude and wildly.
Why bear you these rebukes and answer not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: She did betray me to my own reproof.
Good people enter and lay hold on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: No, not a creature enters in my house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Then let your servants bring my husband forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Neither: he took this place for sanctuary,
And it shall privilege him from your hands
Till I have brought him to his wits again,
Or lose my labour in assaying it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I will attend my husband, be his nurse,
Diet his sickness, for it is my office,
And will have no attorney but myself;
And therefore let me have him home with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Be patient; for I will not let him stir
Till I have used the approved means I have,
With wholesome syrups, drugs and holy prayers,
To make of him a formal man again:
It is a branch and parcel of mine oath,
A charitable duty of my order.
Therefore depart and leave him here with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I will not hence and leave my husband here:
And ill it doth beseem your holiness
To separate the husband and the wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Be quiet and depart: thou shalt not have him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Complain unto the duke of this indignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Come, go: I will fall prostrate at his feet
And never rise until my tears and prayers
Have won his grace to come in person hither
And take perforce my husband from the abbess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: By this, I think, the dial points at five:
Anon, I'm sure, the duke himself in person
Comes this way to the melancholy vale,
The place of death and sorry execution,
Behind the ditches of the abbey here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: Upon what cause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant,
Who put unluckily into this bay
Against the laws and statutes of this town,
Beheaded publicly for his offence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: See where they come: we will behold his death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Yet once again proclaim it publicly,
If any friend will pay the sum for him,
He shall not die; so much we tender him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Justice, most sacred duke, against the abbess!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: She is a virtuous and a reverend lady:
It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: May it please your grace, Antipholus, my husband,
Whom I made lord of me and all I had,
At your important letters,--this ill day
A most outrageous fit of madness took him;
That desperately he hurried through the street,
With him his bondman, all as mad as he--
Doing displeasure to the citizens
By rushing in their houses, bearing thence
Rings, jewels, any thing his rage did like.
Once did I get him bound and sent him home,
Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went,
That here and there his fury had committed.
Anon, I wot not by what strong escape,
He broke from those that had the guard of him;
And with his mad attendant and himself,
Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords,
Met us again and madly bent on us,
Chased us away; till, raising of more aid,
We came again to bind them. Then they fled
Into this abbey, whither we pursued them:
And here the abbess shuts the gates on us
And will not suffer us to fetch him out,
Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence.
Therefore, most gracious duke, with thy command
Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Long since thy husband served me in my wars,
And I to thee engaged a prince's word,
When thou didst make him master of thy bed,
To do him all the grace and good I could.
Go, some of you, knock at the abbey-gate
And bid the lady abbess come to me.
I will determine this before I stir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: O mistress, mistress, shift and save yourself!
My master and his man are both broke loose,
Beaten the maids a-row and bound the doctor
Whose beard they have singed off with brands of fire;
And ever, as it blazed, they threw on him
Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair:
My master preaches patience to him and the while
His man with scissors nicks him like a fool,
And sure, unless you send some present help,
Between them they will kill the conjurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, fool! thy master and his man are here,
And that is false thou dost report to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true;
I have not breathed almost since I did see it.
He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you,
To scorch your face and to disfigure you.
Hark, hark! I hear him, mistress. fly, be gone!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, stand by me; fear nothing. Guard with halberds!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me, it is my husband! Witness you,
That he is borne about invisible:
Even now we housed him in the abbey here;
And now he's there, past thought of human reason.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Justice, most gracious duke, O, grant me justice!
Even for the service that long since I did thee,
When I bestrid thee in the wars and took
Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood
That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Unless the fear of death doth make me dote,
I see my son Antipholus and Dromio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Justice, sweet prince, against that woman there!
She whom thou gavest to me to be my wife,
That hath abused and dishonour'd me
Even in the strength and height of injury!
Beyond imagination is the wrong
That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: This day, great duke, she shut the doors upon me,
While she with harlots feasted in my house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: A grievous fault! Say, woman, didst thou so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: No, my good lord: myself, he and my sister
To-day did dine together. So befall my soul
As this is false he burdens me withal!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Ne'er may I look on day, nor sleep on night,
But she tells to your highness simple truth!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: O perjured woman! They are both forsworn:
In this the madman justly chargeth them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: My liege, I am advised what I say,
Neither disturbed with the effect of wine,
Nor heady-rash, provoked with raging ire,
Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.
This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner:
That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her,
Could witness it, for he was with me then;
Who parted with me to go fetch a chain,
Promising to bring it to the Porpentine,
Where Balthazar and I did dine together.
Our dinner done, and he not coming thither,
I went to seek him: in the street I met him
And in his company that gentleman.
There did this perjured goldsmith swear me down
That I this day of him received the chain,
Which, God he knows, I saw not: for the which
He did arrest me with an officer.
I did obey, and sent my peasant home
For certain ducats: he with none return'd
Then fairly I bespoke the officer
To go in person with me to my house.
By the way we met
My wife, her sister, and a rabble more
Of vile confederates. Along with them
They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-faced villain,
A mere anatomy, a mountebank,
A threadbare juggler and a fortune-teller,
A needy, hollow-eyed, sharp-looking wretch,
A dead-looking man: this pernicious slave,
Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer,
And, gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,
And with no face, as 'twere, outfacing me,
Cries out, I was possess'd. Then all together
They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence
And in a dark and dankish vault at home
There left me and my man, both bound together;
Till, gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder,
I gain'd my freedom, and immediately
Ran hither to your grace; whom I beseech
To give me ample satisfaction
For these deep shames and great indignities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, in truth, thus far I witness with him,
That he dined not at home, but was lock'd out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: But had he such a chain of thee or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: He had, my lord: and when he ran in here,
These people saw the chain about his neck.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Merchant
SPEECH.LINE: Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine
Heard you confess you had the chain of him
After you first forswore it on the mart:
And thereupon I drew my sword on you;
And then you fled into this abbey here,
From whence, I think, you are come by miracle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I never came within these abbey-walls,
Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me:
I never saw the chain, so help me Heaven!
And this is false you burden me withal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what an intricate impeach is this!
I think you all have drunk of Circe's cup.
If here you housed him, here he would have been;
If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly:
You say he dined at home; the goldsmith here
Denies that saying. Sirrah, what say you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, he dined with her there, at the Porpentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: He did, and from my finger snatch'd that ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: As sure, my liege, as I do see your grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this is strange. Go call the abbess hither.
I think you are all mated or stark mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word:
Haply I see a friend will save my life
And pay the sum that may deliver me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Speak freely, Syracusian, what thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Is not your name, sir, call'd Antipholus?
And is not that your bondman, Dromio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Within this hour I was his bondman sir,
But he, I thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords:
Now am I Dromio and his man unbound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: I am sure you both of you remember me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ourselves we do remember, sir, by you;
For lately we were bound, as you are now
You are not Pinch's patient, are you, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Why look you strange on me? you know me well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: O, grief hath changed me since you saw me last,
And careful hours with time's deformed hand
Have written strange defeatures in my face:
But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Dromio, nor thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, trust me, sir, nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: I am sure thou dost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, sir, but I am sure I do not; and whatsoever a
man denies, you are now bound to believe him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: Not know my voice! O time's extremity,
Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue
In seven short years, that here my only son
Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares?
Though now this grained face of mine be hid
In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow,
And all the conduits of my blood froze up,
Yet hath my night of life some memory,
My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left,
My dull deaf ears a little use to hear:
All these old witnesses--I cannot err--
Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I never saw my father in my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: But seven years since, in Syracusa, boy,
Thou know'st we parted: but perhaps, my son,
Thou shamest to acknowledge me in misery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: The duke and all that know me in the city
Can witness with me that it is not so
I ne'er saw Syracusa in my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years
Have I been patron to Antipholus,
During which time he ne'er saw Syracusa:
I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter AEMILIA, with ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse and DROMIO of Syracuse

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Most mighty duke, behold a man much wrong'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: One of these men is Genius to the other;
And so of these. Which is the natural man,
And which the spirit? who deciphers them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I, sir, am Dromio; command him away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I, sir, am Dromio; pray, let me stay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: AEgeon art thou not? or else his ghost?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: O, my old master! who hath bound him here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds
And gain a husband by his liberty.
Speak, old AEgeon, if thou be'st the man
That hadst a wife once call'd AEmilia
That bore thee at a burden two fair sons:
O, if thou be'st the same AEgeon, speak,
And speak unto the same AEmilia!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEGEON
SPEECH.LINE: If I dream not, thou art AEmilia:
If thou art she, tell me where is that son
That floated with thee on the fatal raft?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: By men of Epidamnum he and I
And the twin Dromio all were taken up;
But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth
By force took Dromio and my son from them
And me they left with those of Epidamnum.
What then became of them I cannot tell
I to this fortune that you see me in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, here begins his morning story right;
These two Antipholuses, these two so like,
And these two Dromios, one in semblance,--
Besides her urging of her wreck at sea,--
These are the parents to these children,
Which accidentally are met together.
Antipholus, thou camest from Corinth first?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir, not I; I came from Syracuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, stand apart; I know not which is which.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And I with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior,
Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: Which of you two did dine with me to-day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I, gentle mistress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: And are not you my husband?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: No; I say nay to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: And so do I; yet did she call me so:
And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here,
Did call me brother.
What I told you then,
I hope I shall have leisure to make good;
If this be not a dream I see and hear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: I think it be, sir; I deny it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANGELO
SPEECH.LINE: I think I did, sir; I deny it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ADRIANA
SPEECH.LINE: I sent you money, sir, to be your bail,
By Dromio; but I think he brought it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, none by me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: This purse of ducats I received from you,
And Dromio, my man, did bring them me.
I see we still did meet each other's man,
And I was ta'en for him, and he for me,
And thereupon these errors are arose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: These ducats pawn I for my father here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: It shall not need; thy father hath his life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtezan
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I must have that diamond from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: There, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEMELIA
SPEECH.LINE: Renowned duke, vouchsafe to take the pains
To go with us into the abbey here
And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes:
And all that are assembled in this place,
That by this sympathized one day's error
Have suffer'd wrong, go keep us company,
And we shall make full satisfaction.
Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail
Of you, my sons; and till this present hour
My heavy burden ne'er delivered.
The duke, my husband and my children both,
And you the calendars of their nativity,
Go to a gossips' feast and go with me;
After so long grief, such festivity!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE SOLINUS
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart, I'll gossip at this feast.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse, Antipholus of Ephesus, Dromio of Syracuse and Dromio of Ephesus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Master, shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark'd?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: He speaks to me. I am your master, Dromio:
Come, go with us; we'll look to that anon:
Embrace thy brother there; rejoice with him.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: There is a fat friend at your master's house,
That kitchen'd me for you to-day at dinner:
She now shall be my sister, not my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother:
I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth.
Will you walk in to see their gossiping?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, sir; you are my elder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: That's a question: how shall we try it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
SPEECH.LINE: We'll draw cuts for the senior: till then lead thou first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, then, thus:
We came into the world like brother and brother;
And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.

PLAY.TITLE: The Tragedy of Coriolanus

PERSONAE.TITLE: Dramatis Personae
PERSONAE.PERSONA: CAIUS MARCIUS, Afterwards CAIUS MARCIUS CORIOLANUS.
TULLUS AUFIDIUS, general of the Volscians.
Roman and Volscian Senators, Patricians, Aediles, Lictors, Soldiers, Citizens, Messengers, Servants to Aufidius, and other Attendants.

PLAY.SCNDESCR: SCENE Rome and the neighbourhood; Corioli and the neighbourhood; Antium.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rome. A street.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a company of mutinous Citizens, with staves, clubs, and other weapons

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Speak, speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Resolved. resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: We know't, we know't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.
Is't a verdict?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: One word, good citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good.
What authority surfeits on would relieve us: if they
would yield us but the superfluity, while it were
wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely;
but they think we are too dear: the leanness that
afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an
inventory to particularise their abundance; our
sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with
our pikes, ere we become rakes: for the gods know I
speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Consider you what services he has done for his country?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Very well; and could be content to give him good
report fort, but that he pays himself with being proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did
it to that end: though soft-conscienced men can be
content to say it was for his country he did it to
please his mother and to be partly proud; which he
is, even till the altitude of his virtue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: What he cannot help in his nature, you account a
vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations;
he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition.
What shouts are these? The other side o' the city
is risen: why stay we prating here? to the Capitol!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Soft! who comes here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved
the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go you
With bats and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have
had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do,
which now we'll show 'em in deeds. They say poor
suitors have strong breaths: they shall know we
have strong arms too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,
Will you undo yourselves?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I tell you, friends, most charitable care
Have the patricians of you. For your wants,
Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well
Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
Against the Roman state, whose course will on
The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,
The gods, not the patricians, make it, and
Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack,
You are transported by calamity
Thither where more attends you, and you slander
The helms o' the state, who care for you like fathers,
When you curse them as enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Care for us! True, indeed! They ne'er cared for us
yet: suffer us to famish, and their store-houses
crammed with grain; make edicts for usury, to
support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act
established against the rich, and provide more
piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain
the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and
there's all the love they bear us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Either you must
Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,
Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you
A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;
But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture
To stale 't a little more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I'll hear it, sir: yet you must not think to
fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please
you, deliver.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: There was a time when all the body's members
Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it:
That only like a gulf it did remain
I' the midst o' the body, idle and unactive,
Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing
Like labour with the rest, where the other instruments
Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
And, mutually participate, did minister
Unto the appetite and affection common
Of the whole body. The belly answer'd--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir, what answer made the belly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile,
Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus--
For, look you, I may make the belly smile
As well as speak--it tauntingly replied
To the discontented members, the mutinous parts
That envied his receipt; even so most fitly
As you malign our senators for that
They are not such as you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Your belly's answer? What!
The kingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye,
The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier,
Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter.
With other muniments and petty helps
In this our fabric, if that they--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What then?
'Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? what then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd,
Who is the sink o' the body,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: The former agents, if they did complain,
What could the belly answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell you
If you'll bestow a small--of what you have little--
Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Ye're long about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Note me this, good friend;
Your most grave belly was deliberate,
Not rash like his accusers, and thus answer'd:
'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he,
'That I receive the general food at first,
Which you do live upon; and fit it is,
Because I am the store-house and the shop
Of the whole body: but, if you do remember,
I send it through the rivers of your blood,
Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain;
And, through the cranks and offices of man,
The strongest nerves and small inferior veins
From me receive that natural competency
Whereby they live: and though that all at once,
You, my good friends,'--this says the belly, mark me,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, sir; well, well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Though all at once cannot
See what I do deliver out to each,
Yet I can make my audit up, that all
From me do back receive the flour of all,
And leave me but the bran.' What say you to't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: It was an answer: how apply you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The senators of Rome are this good belly,
And you the mutinous members; for examine
Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly
Touching the weal o' the common, you shall find
No public benefit which you receive
But it proceeds or comes from them to you
And no way from yourselves. What do you think,
You, the great toe of this assembly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: I the great toe! why the great toe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: For that, being one o' the lowest, basest, poorest,
Of this most wise rebellion, thou go'st foremost:
Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run,
Lead'st first to win some vantage.
But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs:
Rome and her rats are at the point of battle;
The one side must have bale.
Hail, noble Marcius!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks. What's the matter, you dissentious rogues,
That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion,
Make yourselves scabs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We have ever your good word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He that will give good words to thee will flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs,
That like nor peace nor war? the one affrights you,
The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you,
Where he should find you lions, finds you hares;
Where foxes, geese: you are no surer, no,
Than is the coal of fire upon the ice,
Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is
To make him worthy whose offence subdues him
And curse that justice did it.
Who deserves greatness
Deserves your hate; and your affections are
A sick man's appetite, who desires most that
Which would increase his evil. He that depends
Upon your favours swims with fins of lead
And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust Ye?
With every minute you do change a mind,
And call him noble that was now your hate,
Him vile that was your garland. What's the matter,
That in these several places of the city
You cry against the noble senate, who,
Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else
Would feed on one another? What's their seeking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: For corn at their own rates; whereof, they say,
The city is well stored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hang 'em! They say!
They'll sit by the fire, and presume to know
What's done i' the Capitol; who's like to rise,
Who thrives and who declines; side factions
and give out
Conjectural marriages; making parties strong
And feebling such as stand not in their liking
Below their cobbled shoes. They say there's
grain enough!
Would the nobility lay aside their ruth,
And let me use my sword, I'll make a quarry
With thousands of these quarter'd slaves, as high
As I could pick my lance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded;
For though abundantly they lack discretion,
Yet are they passing cowardly. But, I beseech you,
What says the other troop?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: They are dissolved: hang 'em!
They said they were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs,
That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat,
That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not
Corn for the rich men only: with these shreds
They vented their complainings; which being answer'd,
And a petition granted them, a strange one--
To break the heart of generosity,
And make bold power look pale--they threw their caps
As they would hang them on the horns o' the moon,
Shouting their emulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What is granted them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms,
Of their own choice: one's Junius Brutus,
Sicinius Velutus, and I know not--'Sdeath!
The rabble should have first unroof'd the city,
Ere so prevail'd with me: it will in time
Win upon power and throw forth greater themes
For insurrection's arguing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This is strange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, get you home, you fragments!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Where's Caius Marcius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here: what's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad on 't: then we shall ha' means to vent
Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, and other Senators; JUNIUS BRUTUS and SICINIUS VELUTUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us;
The Volsces are in arms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: They have a leader,
Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to 't.
I sin in envying his nobility,
And were I any thing but what I am,
I would wish me only he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You have fought together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Were half to half the world by the ears and he.
Upon my party, I'ld revolt to make
Only my wars with him: he is a lion
That I am proud to hunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Then, worthy Marcius,
Attend upon Cominius to these wars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: It is your former promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, it is;
And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou
Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face.
What, art thou stiff? stand'st out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TITUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, Caius Marcius;
I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other,
Ere stay behind this business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, true-bred!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Your company to the Capitol; where, I know,
Our greatest friends attend us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TITUS
SPEECH.LINE: To COMINIUS Lead you on.
To MARCIUS Follow Cominius; we must follow you;
Right worthy you priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Marcius!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: To the Citizens Hence to your homes; be gone!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, let them follow:
The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither
To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners,
Your valour puts well forth: pray, follow.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Citizens steal away. Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: He has no equal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: When we were chosen tribunes for the people,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Mark'd you his lip and eyes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay. but his taunts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Be-mock the modest moon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: The present wars devour him: he is grown
Too proud to be so valiant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Such a nature,
Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow
Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder
His insolence can brook to be commanded
Under Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fame, at the which he aims,
In whom already he's well graced, can not
Better be held nor more attain'd than by
A place below the first: for what miscarries
Shall be the general's fault, though he perform
To the utmost of a man, and giddy censure
Will then cry out of Marcius 'O if he
Had borne the business!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Besides, if things go well,
Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall
Of his demerits rob Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come:
Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius.
Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults
To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed
In aught he merit not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let's hence, and hear
How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion,
More than his singularity, he goes
Upon this present action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Lets along.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. Corioli. The Senate-house.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS and certain Senators

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: So, your opinion is, Aufidius,
That they of Rome are entered in our counsels
And know how we proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Is it not yours?
What ever have been thought on in this state,
That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome
Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone
Since I heard thence; these are the words: I think
I have the letter here; yes, here it is.
'They have press'd a power, but it is not known
Whether for east or west: the dearth is great;
The people mutinous; and it is rumour'd,
Cominius, Marcius your old enemy,
Who is of Rome worse hated than of you,
And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman,
These three lead on this preparation
Whither 'tis bent: most likely 'tis for you:
Consider of it.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Our army's in the field
We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
To answer us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nor did you think it folly
To keep your great pretences veil'd till when
They needs must show themselves; which
in the hatching,
It seem'd, appear'd to Rome. By the discovery.
We shall be shorten'd in our aim, which was
To take in many towns ere almost Rome
Should know we were afoot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Aufidius,
Take your commission; hie you to your bands:
Let us alone to guard Corioli:
If they set down before 's, for the remove
Bring your army; but, I think, you'll find
They've not prepared for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, doubt not that;
I speak from certainties. Nay, more,
Some parcels of their power are forth already,
And only hitherward. I leave your honours.
If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet,
'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike
Till one can do no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: The gods assist you!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: And keep your honours safe!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA they set them down on two low stools, and sew

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself in a
more comfortable sort: if my son were my husband, I
should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he
won honour than in the embracements of his bed where
he would show most love. When yet he was but
tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, when
youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way, when
for a day of kings' entreaties a mother should not
sell him an hour from her beholding, I, considering
how honour would become such a person. that it was
no better than picture-like to hang by the wall, if
renown made it not stir, was pleased to let him seek
danger where he was like to find fame. To a cruel
war I sent him; from whence he returned, his brows
bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not
more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child
than now in first seeing he had proved himself a
man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: But had he died in the business, madam; how then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Then his good report should have been my son; I
therein would have found issue. Hear me profess
sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love
alike and none less dear than thine and my good
Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their
country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gentlewoman
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, you shall not.
Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum,
See him pluck Aufidius down by the hair,
As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him:
Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:
'Come on, you cowards! you were got in fear,
Though you were born in Rome:' his bloody brow
With his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes,
Like to a harvest-man that's task'd to mow
Or all or lose his hire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: His bloody brow! O Jupiter, no blood!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Away, you fool! it more becomes a man
Than gilt his trophy: the breasts of Hecuba,
When she did suckle Hector, look'd not lovelier
Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood
At Grecian sword, contemning. Tell Valeria,
We are fit to bid her welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee
And tread upon his neck.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter VALERIA, with an Usher and Gentlewoman

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: My ladies both, good day to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to see your ladyship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: How do you both? you are manifest house-keepers.
What are you sewing here? A fine spot, in good
faith. How does your little son?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: He had rather see the swords, and hear a drum, than
look upon his school-master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: O' my word, the father's son: I'll swear,'tis a
very pretty boy. O' my troth, I looked upon him o'
Wednesday half an hour together: has such a
confirmed countenance. I saw him run after a gilded
butterfly: and when he caught it, he let it go
again; and after it again; and over and over he
comes, and again; catched it again; or whether his
fall enraged him, or how 'twas, he did so set his
teeth and tear it; O, I warrant it, how he mammocked
it!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: One on 's father's moods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: A crack, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play
the idle husewife with me this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: No, good madam; I will not out of doors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: Not out of doors!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: She shall, she shall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, no, by your patience; I'll not over the
threshold till my lord return from the wars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably: come,
you must go visit the good lady that lies in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with
my prayers; but I cannot go thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: You would be another Penelope: yet, they say, all
the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill
Ithaca full of moths. Come; I would your cambric
were sensible as your finger, that you might leave
pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you
excellent news of your husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: O, good madam, there can be none yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from
him last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it.
Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against
whom Cominius the general is gone, with one part of
our Roman power: your lord and Titus Lartius are set
down before their city Corioli; they nothing doubt
prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true,
on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every
thing hereafter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Let her alone, lady: as she is now, she will but
disease our better mirth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: In troth, I think she would. Fare you well, then.
Come, good sweet lady. Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy
solemness out o' door. and go along with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: No, at a word, madam; indeed, I must not. I wish
you much mirth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: Well, then, farewell.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. Before Corioli.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, with drum and colours, MARCIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, Captains and Soldiers. To them a Messenger

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: My horse to yours, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Agreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Say, has our general met the enemy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: They lie in view; but have not spoke as yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: So, the good horse is mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll buy him of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, I'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him I will
For half a hundred years. Summon the town.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: How far off lie these armies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Within this mile and half.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours.
Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work,
That we with smoking swords may march from hence,
To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: They sound a parley. Enter two Senators with others on the walls
SPEECH.LINE: Tutus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: No, nor a man that fears you less than he,
That's lesser than a little.
Hark! our drums
Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls,
Rather than they shall pound us up: our gates,
Which yet seem shut, we, have but pinn'd with rushes;
They'll open of themselves.
Hark you. far off!
There is Aufidius; list, what work he makes
Amongst your cloven army.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, they are at it!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the army of the Volsces

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: They fear us not, but issue forth their city.
Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight
With hearts more proof than shields. Advance,
brave Titus:
They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,
Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows:
He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce,
And he shall feel mine edge.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum. The Romans are beat back to their trenches. Re-enter MARCIUS cursing

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: All the contagion of the south light on you,
You shames of Rome! you herd of--Boils and plagues
Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'd
Further than seen and one infect another
Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese,
That bear the shapes of men, how have you run
From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!
All hurt behind; backs red, and faces pale
With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home,
Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe
And make my wars on you: look to't: come on;
If you'll stand fast, we'll beat them to their wives,
As they us to our trenches followed.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Another alarum. The Volsces fly, and MARCIUS follows them to the gates
SPEECH.LINE: So, now the gates are ope: now prove good seconds:
'Tis for the followers fortune widens them,
Not for the fliers: mark me, and do the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: Fool-hardiness; not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: See, they have shut him in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: To the pot, I warrant him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What is become of Marcius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Slain, sir, doubtless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: Following the fliers at the very heels,
With them he enters; who, upon the sudden,
Clapp'd to their gates: he is himself alone,
To answer all the city.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O noble fellow!
Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword,
And, when it bows, stands up. Thou art left, Marcius:
A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art,
Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier
Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible
Only in strokes; but, with thy grim looks and
The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds,
Thou madst thine enemies shake, as if the world
Were feverous and did tremble.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter MARCIUS, bleeding, assaulted by the enemy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: Look, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O,'tis Marcius!
Let's fetch him off, or make remain alike.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: They fight, and all enter the city

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. Corioli. A street.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Roman
SPEECH.LINE: This will I carry to Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Roman
SPEECH.LINE: And I this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Roman
SPEECH.LINE: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS with a trumpet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: See here these movers that do prize their hours
At a crack'd drachm! Cushions, leaden spoons,
Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would
Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves,
Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!
And hark, what noise the general makes! To him!
There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius,
Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take
Convenient numbers to make good the city;
Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste
To help Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st;
Thy exercise hath been too violent for
A second course of fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, praise me not;
My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well:
The blood I drop is rather physical
Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus
I will appear, and fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Now the fair goddess, Fortune,
Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms
Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman,
Prosperity be thy page!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thy friend no less
Than those she placeth highest! So, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thou worthiest Marcius!
Go, sound thy trumpet in the market-place;
Call thither all the officers o' the town,
Where they shall know our mind: away!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VI. Near the camp of Cominius.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter COMINIUS, as it were in retire, with soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Breathe you, my friends: well fought;
we are come off
Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands,
Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs,
We shall be charged again. Whiles we have struck,
By interims and conveying gusts we have heard
The charges of our friends. Ye Roman gods!
Lead their successes as we wish our own,
That both our powers, with smiling
fronts encountering,
May give you thankful sacrifice.
Thy news?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: The citizens of Corioli have issued,
And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle:
I saw our party to their trenches driven,
And then I came away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Though thou speak'st truth,
Methinks thou speak'st not well.
How long is't since?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Above an hour, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums:
How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour,
And bring thy news so late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Spies of the Volsces
Held me in chase, that I was forced to wheel
Three or four miles about, else had I, sir,
Half an hour since brought my report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Who's yonder,
That does appear as he were flay'd? O gods
He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have
Before-time seen him thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Within Come I too late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour
More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue
From every meaner man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come I too late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,
But mantled in your own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, let me clip ye
In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart
As merry as when our nuptial day was done,
And tapers burn'd to bedward!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Flower of warriors,
How is it with Titus Lartius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: As with a man busied about decrees:
Condemning some to death, and some to exile;
Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other;
Holding Corioli in the name of Rome,
Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,
To let him slip at will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Where is that slave
Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?
Where is he? call him hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let him alone;
He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen,
The common file--a plague! tribunes for them!--
The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge
From rascals worse than they.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: But how prevail'd you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Will the time serve to tell? I do not think.
Where is the enemy? are you lords o' the field?
If not, why cease you till you are so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Marcius,
We have at disadvantage fought and did
Retire to win our purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: How lies their battle? know you on which side
They have placed their men of trust?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: As I guess, Marcius,
Their bands i' the vaward are the Antiates,
Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius,
Their very heart of hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I do beseech you,
By all the battles wherein we have fought,
By the blood we have shed together, by the vows
We have made to endure friends, that you directly
Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates;
And that you not delay the present, but,
Filling the air with swords advanced and darts,
We prove this very hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Though I could wish
You were conducted to a gentle bath
And balms applied to, you, yet dare I never
Deny your asking: take your choice of those
That best can aid your action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Those are they
That most are willing. If any such be here--
As it were sin to doubt--that love this painting
Wherein you see me smear'd; if any fear
Lesser his person than an ill report;
If any think brave death outweighs bad life
And that his country's dearer than himself;
Let him alone, or so many so minded,
Wave thus, to express his disposition,
And follow Marcius.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: They all shout and wave their swords, take him up in their arms, and cast up their caps
SPEECH.LINE: O, me alone! make you a sword of me?
If these shows be not outward, which of you
But is four Volsces? none of you but is
Able to bear against the great Aufidius
A shield as hard as his. A certain number,
Though thanks to all, must I select
from all: the rest
Shall bear the business in some other fight,
As cause will be obey'd. Please you to march;
And four shall quickly draw out my command,
Which men are best inclined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: March on, my fellows:
Make good this ostentation, and you shall
Divide in all with us.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VII. The gates of Corioli.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: TITUS LARTIUS, having set a guard upon Corioli, going with drum and trumpet toward COMINIUS and CAIUS MARCIUS, enters with Lieutenant, other Soldiers, and a Scout

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: So, let the ports be guarded: keep your duties,
As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch
Those centuries to our aid: the rest will serve
For a short holding: if we lose the field,
We cannot keep the town.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieutenant
SPEECH.LINE: Fear not our care, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hence, and shut your gates upon's.
Our guider, come; to the Roman camp conduct us.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VIII. A field of battle.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum as in battle. Enter, from opposite sides, MARCIUS and AUFIDIUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll fight with none but thee; for I do hate thee
Worse than a promise-breaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: We hate alike:
Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let the first budger die the other's slave,
And the gods doom him after!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: If I fly, Marcius,
Holloa me like a hare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Within these three hours, Tullus,
Alone I fought in your Corioli walls,
And made what work I pleased: 'tis not my blood
Wherein thou seest me mask'd; for thy revenge
Wrench up thy power to the highest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Wert thou the Hector
That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny,
Thou shouldst not scape me here.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: They fight, and certain Volsces come to the aid of AUFIDIUS. MARCIUS fights till they be driven in breathless
SPEECH.LINE: Officious, and not valiant, you have shamed me
In your condemned seconds.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IX. The Roman camp.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Alarum. A retreat is sounded. Flourish. Enter, from one side, COMINIUS with the Romans; from the other side, MARCIUS, with his arm in a scarf

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work,
Thou'ldst not believe thy deeds: but I'll report it
Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles,
Where great patricians shall attend and shrug,
I' the end admire, where ladies shall be frighted,
And, gladly quaked, hear more; where the
dull tribunes,
That, with the fusty plebeians, hate thine honours,
Shall say against their hearts 'We thank the gods
Our Rome hath such a soldier.'
Yet camest thou to a morsel of this feast,
Having fully dined before.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter TITUS LARTIUS, with his power, from the pursuit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O general,
Here is the steed, we the caparison:
Hadst thou beheld--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pray now, no more: my mother,
Who has a charter to extol her blood,
When she does praise me grieves me. I have done
As you have done; that's what I can; induced
As you have been; that's for my country:
He that has but effected his good will
Hath overta'en mine act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You shall not be
The grave of your deserving; Rome must know
The value of her own: 'twere a concealment
Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement,
To hide your doings; and to silence that,
Which, to the spire and top of praises vouch'd,
Would seem but modest: therefore, I beseech you
In sign of what you are, not to reward
What you have done--before our army hear me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I have some wounds upon me, and they smart
To hear themselves remember'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Should they not,
Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude,
And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses,
Whereof we have ta'en good and good store, of all
The treasure in this field achieved and city,
We render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth,
Before the common distribution, at
Your only choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you, general;
But cannot make my heart consent to take
A bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it;
And stand upon my common part with those
That have beheld the doing.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A long flourish. They all cry 'Marcius! Marcius!' cast up their caps and lances: COMINIUS and LARTIUS stand bare

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: May these same instruments, which you profane,
Never sound more! when drums and trumpets shall
I' the field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be
Made all of false-faced soothing!
When steel grows soft as the parasite's silk,
Let him be made a coverture for the wars!
No more, I say! For that I have not wash'd
My nose that bled, or foil'd some debile wretch.--
Which, without note, here's many else have done,--
You shout me forth
In acclamations hyperbolical;
As if I loved my little should be dieted
In praises sauced with lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Too modest are you;
More cruel to your good report than grateful
To us that give you truly: by your patience,
If 'gainst yourself you be incensed, we'll put you,
Like one that means his proper harm, in manacles,
Then reason safely with you. Therefore, be it known,
As to us, to all the world, that Caius Marcius
Wears this war's garland: in token of the which,
My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him,
With all his trim belonging; and from this time,
For what he did before Corioli, call him,
With all the applause and clamour of the host,
CAIUS MARCIUS CORIOLANUS! Bear
The addition nobly ever!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Caius Marcius Coriolanus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will go wash;
And when my face is fair, you shall perceive
Whether I blush or no: howbeit, I thank you.
I mean to stride your steed, and at all times
To undercrest your good addition
To the fairness of my power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: So, to our tent;
Where, ere we do repose us, we will write
To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius,
Must to Corioli back: send us to Rome
The best, with whom we may articulate,
For their own good and ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I shall, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: The gods begin to mock me. I, that now
Refused most princely gifts, am bound to beg
Of my lord general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Take't; 'tis yours. What is't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I sometime lay here in Corioli
At a poor man's house; he used me kindly:
He cried to me; I saw him prisoner;
But then Aufidius was within my view,
And wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity: I request you
To give my poor host freedom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, well begg'd!
Were he the butcher of my son, he should
Be free as is the wind. Deliver him, Titus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Marcius, his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: By Jupiter! forgot.
I am weary; yea, my memory is tired.
Have we no wine here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go we to our tent:
The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time
It should be look'd to: come.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE X. The camp of the Volsces.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: A flourish. Cornets. Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS, bloody, with two or three Soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The town is ta'en!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twill be deliver'd back on good condition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Condition!
I would I were a Roman; for I cannot,
Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition!
What good condition can a treaty find
I' the part that is at mercy? Five times, Marcius,
I have fought with thee: so often hast thou beat me,
And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter
As often as we eat. By the elements,
If e'er again I meet him beard to beard,
He's mine, or I am his: mine emulation
Hath not that honour in't it had; for where
I thought to crush him in an equal force,
True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way
Or wrath or craft may get him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: He's the devil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poison'd
With only suffering stain by him; for him
Shall fly out of itself: nor sleep nor sanctuary,
Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol,
The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice,
Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up
Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst
My hate to Marcius: where I find him, were it
At home, upon my brother's guard, even there,
Against the hospitable canon, would I
Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to the city;
Learn how 'tis held; and what they are that must
Be hostages for Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: Will not you go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AUFIDIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am attended at the cypress grove: I pray you--
'Tis south the city mills--bring me word thither
How the world goes, that to the pace of it
I may spur on my journey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: I shall, sir.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rome. A public place.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter MENENIUS with the two Tribunes of the people, SICINIUS and BRUTUS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Good or bad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they
love not Marcius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you, who does the wolf love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The lamb.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, to devour him; as the hungry plebeians would the
noble Marcius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: He's a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two
are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: In what enormity is Marcius poor in, that you two
have not in abundance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: He's poor in no one fault, but stored with all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Especially in pride.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: And topping all others in boasting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This is strange now: do you two know how you are
censured here in the city, I mean of us o' the
right-hand file? do you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: Why, how are we censured?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Because you talk of pride now,--will you not be angry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, sir, well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of
occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience:
give your dispositions the reins, and be angry at
your pleasures; at the least if you take it as a
pleasure to you in being so. You blame Marcius for
being proud?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: We do it not alone, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I know you can do very little alone; for your helps
are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous
single: your abilities are too infant-like for
doing much alone. You talk of pride: O that you
could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks,
and make but an interior survey of your good selves!
O that you could!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What then, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting,
proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as
any in Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Menenius, you are known well enough too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that
loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying
Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in
favouring the first complaint; hasty and tinder-like
upon too trivial motion; one that converses more
with the buttock of the night than with the forehead
of the morning: what I think I utter, and spend my
malice in my breath. Meeting two such wealsmen as
you are--I cannot call you Lycurguses--if the drink
you give me touch my palate adversely, I make a
crooked face at it. I can't say your worships have
delivered the matter well, when I find the ass in
compound with the major part of your syllables: and
though I must be content to bear with those that say
you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that
tell you you have good faces. If you see this in
the map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known
well enough too? what barm can your bisson
conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be
known well enough too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You know neither me, yourselves nor any thing. You
are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs: you
wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a
cause between an orange wife and a fosset-seller;
and then rejourn the controversy of three pence to a
second day of audience. When you are hearing a
matter between party and party, if you chance to be
pinched with the colic, you make faces like
mummers; set up the bloody flag against all
patience; and, in roaring for a chamber-pot,
dismiss the controversy bleeding the more entangled
by your hearing: all the peace you make in their
cause is, calling both the parties knaves. You are
a pair of strange ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you are well understood to be a
perfecter giber for the table than a necessary
bencher in the Capitol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall
encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When
you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the
wagging of your beards; and your beards deserve not
so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher's
cushion, or to be entombed in an ass's pack-
saddle. Yet you must be saying, Marcius is proud;
who in a cheap estimation, is worth predecessors
since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the
best of 'em were hereditary hangmen. God-den to
your worships: more of your conversation would
infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly
plebeians: I will be bold to take my leave of you.
How now, my as fair as noble ladies,--and the moon,
were she earthly, no nobler,--whither do you follow
