your eyes so fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches; for
the love of Juno, let's go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ha! Marcius coming home!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, worthy Menenius; and with most prosperous
approbation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee. Hoo!
Marcius coming home!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay,'tis true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Look, here's a letter from him: the state hath
another, his wife another; and, I think, there's one
at home for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will make my very house reel tonight: a letter for
me!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, certain, there's a letter for you; I saw't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: A letter for me! it gives me an estate of seven
years' health; in which time I will make a lip at
the physician: the most sovereign prescription in
Galen is but empiricutic, and, to this preservative,
of no better report than a horse-drench. Is he
not wounded? he was wont to come home wounded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: O, no, no, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: O, he is wounded; I thank the gods for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: So do I too, if it be not too much: brings a'
victory in his pocket? the wounds become him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: On's brows: Menenius, he comes the third time home
with the oaken garland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but
Aufidius got off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that:
an he had stayed by him, I would not have been so
fidiused for all the chests in Corioli, and the gold
that's in them. Is the senate possessed of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Good ladies, let's go. Yes, yes, yes; the senate
has letters from the general, wherein he gives my
son the whole name of the war: he hath in this
action outdone his former deeds doubly

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALERIA
SPEECH.LINE: In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Wondrous! ay, I warrant you, and not without his
true purchasing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: The gods grant them true!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: True! pow, wow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: True! I'll be sworn they are true.
Where is he wounded?
God save your good worships! Marcius is coming
home: he has more cause to be proud. Where is he wounded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: I' the shoulder and i' the left arm there will be
large cicatrices to show the people, when he shall
stand for his place. He received in the repulse of
Tarquin seven hurts i' the body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: One i' the neck, and two i' the thigh,--there's
nine that I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five
wounds upon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Now it's twenty-seven: every gash was an enemy's grave.
Hark! the trumpets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: These are the ushers of Marcius: before him he
carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears:
Death, that dark spirit, in 's nervy arm doth lie;
Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A sennet. Trumpets sound. Enter COMINIUS the general, and TITUS LARTIUS; between them, CORIOLANUS, crowned with an oaken garland; with Captains and Soldiers, and a Herald

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herald
SPEECH.LINE: Know, Rome, that all alone Marcius did fight
Within Corioli gates: where he hath won,
With fame, a name to Caius Marcius; these
In honour follows Coriolanus.
Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: No more of this; it does offend my heart:
Pray now, no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Look, sir, your mother!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: O,
You have, I know, petition'd all the gods
For my prosperity!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, my good soldier, up;
My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and
By deed-achieving honour newly named,--
What is it?--Coriolanus must I call thee?--
But O, thy wife!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious silence, hail!
Wouldst thou have laugh'd had I come coffin'd home,
That weep'st to see me triumph? Ay, my dear,
Such eyes the widows in Corioli wear,
And mothers that lack sons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Now, the gods crown thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: And live you yet?
O my sweet lady, pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: I know not where to turn: O, welcome home:
And welcome, general: and ye're welcome all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep
And I could laugh, I am light and heavy. Welcome.
A curse begin at very root on's heart,
That is not glad to see thee! You are three
That Rome should dote on: yet, by the faith of men,
We have some old crab-trees here
at home that will not
Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors:
We call a nettle but a nettle and
The faults of fools but folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ever right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Menenius ever, ever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herald
SPEECH.LINE: Give way there, and go on!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: To VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA Your hand, and yours:
Ere in our own house I do shade my head,
The good patricians must be visited;
From whom I have received not only greetings,
But with them change of honours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: I have lived
To see inherited my very wishes
And the buildings of my fancy: only
There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but
Our Rome will cast upon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Know, good mother,
I had rather be their servant in my way,
Than sway with them in theirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: On, to the Capitol!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Cornets. Exeunt in state, as before. BRUTUS and SICINIUS come forward

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights
Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse
Into a rapture lets her baby cry
While she chats him: the kitchen malkin pins
Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck,
Clambering the walls to eye him: stalls, bulks, windows,
Are smother'd up, leads fill'd, and ridges horsed
With variable complexions, all agreeing
In earnestness to see him: seld-shown flamens
Do press among the popular throngs and puff
To win a vulgar station: or veil'd dames
Commit the war of white and damask in
Their nicely-gawded cheeks to the wanton spoil
Of Phoebus' burning kisses: such a pother
As if that whatsoever god who leads him
Were slily crept into his human powers
And gave him graceful posture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: On the sudden,
I warrant him consul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then our office may,
During his power, go sleep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot temperately transport his honours
From where he should begin and end, but will
Lose those he hath won.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: In that there's comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Doubt not
The commoners, for whom we stand, but they
Upon their ancient malice will forget
With the least cause these his new honours, which
That he will give them make I as little question
As he is proud to do't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I heard him swear,
Were he to stand for consul, never would he
Appear i' the market-place nor on him put
The napless vesture of humility;
Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds
To the people, beg their stinking breaths.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: It was his word: O, he would miss it rather
Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him,
And the desire of the nobles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I wish no better
Than have him hold that purpose and to put it
In execution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis most like he will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: It shall be to him then as our good wills,
A sure destruction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: So it must fall out
To him or our authorities. For an end,
We must suggest the people in what hatred
He still hath held them; that to's power he would
Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders and
Dispropertied their freedoms, holding them,
In human action and capacity,
Of no more soul nor fitness for the world
Than camels in the war, who have their provand
Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows
For sinking under them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This, as you say, suggested
At some time when his soaring insolence
Shall touch the people--which time shall not want,
If he be put upon 't; and that's as easy
As to set dogs on sheep--will be his fire
To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze
Shall darken him for ever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought
That Marcius shall be consul:
I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and
The blind to bear him speak: matrons flung gloves,
Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers,
Upon him as he pass'd: the nobles bended,
As to Jove's statue, and the commons made
A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts:
I never saw the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let's to the Capitol;
And carry with us ears and eyes for the time,
But hearts for the event.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have with you.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The same. The Capitol.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter two Officers, to lay cushions

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, they are almost here. How many stand
for consulships?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Three, they say: but 'tis thought of every one
Coriolanus will carry it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
SPEECH.LINE: That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and
loves not the common people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Officer
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, there had been many great men that have
flattered the people, who ne'er loved them; and there
be many that they have loved, they know not
wherefore: so that, if they love they know not why,
they hate upon no better a ground: therefore, for
Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate
him manifests the true knowledge he has in their
disposition; and out of his noble carelessness lets
them plainly see't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
SPEECH.LINE: If he did not care whether he had their love or no,
he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither
good nor harm: but he seeks their hate with greater
devotion than can render it him; and leaves
nothing undone that may fully discover him their
opposite. Now, to seem to affect the malice and
displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he
dislikes, to flatter them for their love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Officer
SPEECH.LINE: He hath deserved worthily of his country: and his
ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who,
having been supple and courteous to the people,
bonneted, without any further deed to have them at
an into their estimation and report: but he hath so
planted his honours in their eyes, and his actions
in their hearts, that for their tongues to be
silent, and not confess so much, were a kind of
ingrateful injury; to report otherwise, were a
malice, that, giving itself the lie, would pluck
reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
SPEECH.LINE: No more of him; he is a worthy man: make way, they
are coming.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A sennet. Enter, with actors before them, COMINIUS the consul, MENENIUS, CORIOLANUS, Senators, SICINIUS and BRUTUS. The Senators take their places; the Tribunes take their Places by themselves. CORIOLANUS stands

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Having determined of the Volsces and
To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,
As the main point of this our after-meeting,
To gratify his noble service that
Hath thus stood for his country: therefore,
please you,
Most reverend and grave elders, to desire
The present consul, and last general
In our well-found successes, to report
A little of that worthy work perform'd
By Caius Marcius Coriolanus, whom
We met here both to thank and to remember
With honours like himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Speak, good Cominius:
Leave nothing out for length, and make us think
Rather our state's defective for requital
Than we to stretch it out.
Masters o' the people,
We do request your kindest ears, and after,
Your loving motion toward the common body,
To yield what passes here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: We are convented
Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts
Inclinable to honour and advance
The theme of our assembly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Which the rather
We shall be blest to do, if he remember
A kinder value of the people than
He hath hereto prized them at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: That's off, that's off;
I would you rather had been silent. Please you
To hear Cominius speak?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Most willingly;
But yet my caution was more pertinent
Than the rebuke you give it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He loves your people
But tie him not to be their bedfellow.
Worthy Cominius, speak.
Nay, keep your place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Sit, Coriolanus; never shame to hear
What you have nobly done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Your horror's pardon:
I had rather have my wounds to heal again
Than hear say how I got them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I hope
My words disbench'd you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir: yet oft,
When blows have made me stay, I fled from words.
You soothed not, therefore hurt not: but
your people,
I love them as they weigh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pray now, sit down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun
When the alarum were struck than idly sit
To hear my nothings monster'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Masters of the people,
Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter--
That's thousand to one good one--when you now see
He had rather venture all his limbs for honour
Than one on's ears to hear it? Proceed, Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be utter'd feebly. It is held
That valour is the chiefest virtue, and
Most dignifies the haver: if it be,
The man I speak of cannot in the world
Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years,
When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought
Beyond the mark of others: our then dictator,
Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight,
When with his Amazonian chin he drove
The bristled lips before him: be bestrid
An o'er-press'd Roman and i' the consul's view
Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met,
And struck him on his knee: in that day's feats,
When he might act the woman in the scene,
He proved best man i' the field, and for his meed
Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age
Man-enter'd thus, he waxed like a sea,
And in the brunt of seventeen battles since
He lurch'd all swords of the garland. For this last,
Before and in Corioli, let me say,
I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers;
And by his rare example made the coward
Turn terror into sport: as weeds before
A vessel under sail, so men obey'd
And fell below his stem: his sword, death's stamp,
Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot
He was a thing of blood, whose every motion
Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd
The mortal gate of the city, which he painted
With shunless destiny; aidless came off,
And with a sudden reinforcement struck
Corioli like a planet: now all's his:
When, by and by, the din of war gan pierce
His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit
Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate,
And to the battle came he; where he did
Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if
'Twere a perpetual spoil: and till we call'd
Both field and city ours, he never stood
To ease his breast with panting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy man!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot but with measure fit the honours
Which we devise him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Our spoils he kick'd at,
And look'd upon things precious as they were
The common muck of the world: he covets less
Than misery itself would give; rewards
His deeds with doing them, and is content
To spend the time to end it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He's right noble:
Let him be call'd for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Call Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: He doth appear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased
To make thee consul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I do owe them still
My life and services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: It then remains
That you do speak to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I do beseech you,
Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot
Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them,
For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you
That I may pass this doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the people
Must have their voices; neither will they bate
One jot of ceremony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Put them not to't:
Pray you, go fit you to the custom and
Take to you, as your predecessors have,
Your honour with your form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: It is apart
That I shall blush in acting, and might well
Be taken from the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Mark you that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus;
Show them the unaching scars which I should hide,
As if I had received them for the hire
Of their breath only!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Do not stand upon't.
We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,
Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul
Wish we all joy and honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senators
SPEECH.LINE: To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish of cornets. Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: You see how he intends to use the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: May they perceive's intent! He will require them,
As if he did contemn what he requested
Should be in them to give.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, we'll inform them
Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace,
I know, they do attend us.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. The same. The Forum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We may, sir, if we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a
power that we have no power to do; for if he show us
his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our
tongues into those wounds and speak for them; so, if
he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him
our noble acceptance of them. Ingratitude is
monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful,
were to make a monster of the multitude: of the
which we being members, should bring ourselves to be
monstrous members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: And to make us no better thought of, a little help
will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he
himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We have been called so of many; not that our heads
are some brown, some black, some auburn, some bald,
but that our wits are so diversely coloured: and
truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of
one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south,
and their consent of one direct way should be at
once to all the points o' the compass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would
fly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's
will;'tis strongly wedged up in a block-head, but
if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Why that way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts
melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return
for conscience sake, to help to get thee a wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: You are never without your tricks: you may, you may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Are you all resolved to give your voices? But
that's no matter, the greater part carries it. I
say, if he would incline to the people, there was
never a worthier man.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter CORIOLANUS in a gown of humility, with MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here he comes, and in the gown of humility: mark his
behavior. We are not to stay all together, but to
come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and
by threes. He's to make his requests by
particulars; wherein every one of us has a single
honour, in giving him our own voices with our own
tongues: therefore follow me, and I direct you how
you shall go by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Content, content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O sir, you are not right: have you not known
The worthiest men have done't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: What must I say?
'I Pray, sir'--Plague upon't! I cannot bring
My tongue to such a pace:--'Look, sir, my wounds!
I got them in my country's service, when
Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran
From the noise of our own drums.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O me, the gods!
You must not speak of that: you must desire them
To think upon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Think upon me! hang 'em!
I would they would forget me, like the virtues
Which our divines lose by 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You'll mar all:
I'll leave you: pray you, speak to 'em, I pray you,
In wholesome manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them wash their faces
And keep their teeth clean.
So, here comes a brace.
You know the cause, air, of my standing here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Mine own desert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Your own desert!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but not mine own desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: How not your own desire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir,'twas never my desire yet to trouble the
poor with begging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to
gain by you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, I pray, your price o' the consulship?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: The price is to ask it kindly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Kindly! Sir, I pray, let me ha't: I have wounds to
show you, which shall be yours in private. Your
good voice, sir; what say you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: You shall ha' it, worthy sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices
begged. I have your alms: adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: But this is something odd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: An 'twere to give again,--but 'tis no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your
voices that I may be consul, I have here the
customary gown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you
have not deserved nobly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Your enigma?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: You have been a scourge to her enemies, you have
been a rod to her friends; you have not indeed loved
the common people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: You should account me the more virtuous that I have
not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my
sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer
estimation of them; 'tis a condition they account
gentle: and since the wisdom of their choice is
rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise
the insinuating nod and be off to them most
counterfeitly; that is, sir, I will counterfeit the
bewitchment of some popular man and give it
bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech you,
I may be consul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fifth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give
you our voices heartily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: You have received many wounds for your country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I
will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Most sweet voices!
Better it is to die, better to starve,
Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.
Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here,
To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear,
Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't:
What custom wills, in all things should we do't,
The dust on antique time would lie unswept,
And mountainous error be too highly heapt
For truth to o'er-peer. Rather than fool it so,
Let the high office and the honour go
To one that would do thus. I am half through;
The one part suffer'd, the other will I do.
Here come more voices.
Your voices: for your voices I have fought;
Watch'd for your voices; for Your voices bear
Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six
I have seen and heard of; for your voices have
Done many things, some less, some more your voices:
Indeed I would be consul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sixth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest
man's voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seventh Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore let him be consul: the gods give him joy,
and make him good friend to the people!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy voices!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter MENENIUS, with BRUTUS and SICINIUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You have stood your limitation; and the tribunes
Endue you with the people's voice: remains
That, in the official marks invested, you
Anon do meet the senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Is this done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The custom of request you have discharged:
The people do admit you, and are summon'd
To meet anon, upon your approbation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Where? at the senate-house?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: There, Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: May I change these garments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You may, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again,
Repair to the senate-house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll keep you company. Will you along?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: We stay here for the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fare you well.
He has it now, and by his looks methink
'Tis warm at 's heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds.
will you dismiss the people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: How now, my masters! have you chose this man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: He has our voices, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, sir: to my poor unworthy notice,
He mock'd us when he begg'd our voices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Certainly
He flouted us downright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: No,'tis his kind of speech: he did not mock us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says
He used us scornfully: he should have show'd us
His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, so he did, I am sure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: No, no; no man saw 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: He said he had wounds, which he could show
in private;
And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn,
'I would be consul,' says he: 'aged custom,
But by your voices, will not so permit me;
Your voices therefore.' When we granted that,
Here was 'I thank you for your voices: thank you:
Your most sweet voices: now you have left
your voices,
I have no further with you.' Was not this mockery?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why either were you ignorant to see't,
Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness
To yield your voices?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Could you not have told him
As you were lesson'd, when he had no power,
But was a petty servant to the state,
He was your enemy, ever spake against
Your liberties and the charters that you bear
I' the body of the weal; and now, arriving
A place of potency and sway o' the state,
If he should still malignantly remain
Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might
Be curses to yourselves? You should have said
That as his worthy deeds did claim no less
Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature
Would think upon you for your voices and
Translate his malice towards you into love,
Standing your friendly lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thus to have said,
As you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spirit
And tried his inclination; from him pluck'd
Either his gracious promise, which you might,
As cause had call'd you up, have held him to
Or else it would have gall'd his surly nature,
Which easily endures not article
Tying him to aught; so putting him to rage,
You should have ta'en the advantage of his choler
And pass'd him unelected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Did you perceive
He did solicit you in free contempt
When he did need your loves, and do you think
That his contempt shall not be bruising to you,
When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies
No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry
Against the rectorship of judgment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have you
Ere now denied the asker? and now again
Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow
Your sued-for tongues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: He's not confirm'd; we may deny him yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: And will deny him:
I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: I twice five hundred and their friends to piece 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends,
They have chose a consul that will from them take
Their liberties; make them of no more voice
Than dogs that are as often beat for barking
As therefore kept to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let them assemble,
And on a safer judgment all revoke
Your ignorant election; enforce his pride,
And his old hate unto you; besides, forget not
With what contempt he wore the humble weed,
How in his suit he scorn'd you; but your loves,
Thinking upon his services, took from you
The apprehension of his present portance,
Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion
After the inveterate hate he bears you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Lay
A fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured,
No impediment between, but that you must
Cast your election on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Say, you chose him
More after our commandment than as guided
By your own true affections, and that your minds,
Preoccupied with what you rather must do
Than what you should, made you against the grain
To voice him consul: lay the fault on us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you.
How youngly he began to serve his country,
How long continued, and what stock he springs of,
The noble house o' the Marcians, from whence came
That Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son,
Who, after great Hostilius, here was king;
Of the same house Publius and Quintus were,
That our beat water brought by conduits hither;
And Censorinus, nobly named so,
Twice being by the people chosen censor,
Was his great ancestor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: One thus descended,
That hath beside well in his person wrought
To be set high in place, we did commend
To your remembrances: but you have found,
Scaling his present bearing with his past,
That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke
Your sudden approbation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Say, you ne'er had done't--
Harp on that still--but by our putting on;
And presently, when you have drawn your number,
Repair to the Capitol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: We will so: almost all
Repent in their election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let them go on;
This mutiny were better put in hazard,
Than stay, past doubt, for greater:
If, as his nature is, he fall in rage
With their refusal, both observe and answer
The vantage of his anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: To the Capitol, come:
We will be there before the stream o' the people;
And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own,
Which we have goaded onward.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rome. A street.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Cornets. Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, all the Gentry, COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, and other Senators

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He had, my lord; and that it was which caused
Our swifter composition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: So then the Volsces stand but as at first,
Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road.
Upon's again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: They are worn, lord consul, so,
That we shall hardly in our ages see
Their banners wave again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Saw you Aufidius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: On safe-guard he came to me; and did curse
Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely
Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Spoke he of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He did, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: How? what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: How often he had met you, sword to sword;
That of all things upon the earth he hated
Your person most, that he would pawn his fortunes
To hopeless restitution, so he might
Be call'd your vanquisher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: At Antium lives he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LARTIUS
SPEECH.LINE: At Antium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I wish I had a cause to seek him there,
To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home.
Behold, these are the tribunes of the people,
The tongues o' the common mouth: I do despise them;
For they do prank them in authority,
Against all noble sufferance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pass no further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ha! what is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: It will be dangerous to go on: no further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: What makes this change?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Cominius, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have I had children's voices?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Tribunes, give way; he shall to the market-place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: The people are incensed against him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Stop,
Or all will fall in broil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Are these your herd?
Must these have voices, that can yield them now
And straight disclaim their tongues? What are
your offices?
You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?
Have you not set them on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Be calm, be calm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot,
To curb the will of the nobility:
Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule
Nor ever will be ruled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Call't not a plot:
The people cry you mock'd them, and of late,
When corn was given them gratis, you repined;
Scandal'd the suppliants for the people, call'd them
Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this was known before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Not to them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have you inform'd them sithence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: How! I inform them!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: You are like to do such business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Not unlike,
Each way, to better yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds,
Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me
Your fellow tribune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You show too much of that
For which the people stir: if you will pass
To where you are bound, you must inquire your way,
Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit,
Or never be so noble as a consul,
Nor yoke with him for tribune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let's be calm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The people are abused; set on. This paltering
Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus
Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely
I' the plain way of his merit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me of corn!
This was my speech, and I will speak't again--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Not now, not now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Not in this heat, sir, now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends,
I crave their pardons:
For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them
Regard me as I do not flatter, and
Therein behold themselves: I say again,
In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate
The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition,
Which we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd,
and scatter'd,
By mingling them with us, the honour'd number,
Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that
Which they have given to beggars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: No more words, we beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: How! no more!
As for my country I have shed my blood,
Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs
Coin words till their decay against those measles,
Which we disdain should tatter us, yet sought
The very way to catch them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: You speak o' the people,
As if you were a god to punish, not
A man of their infirmity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere well
We let the people know't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What, what? his choler?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Choler!
Were I as patient as the midnight sleep,
By Jove, 'twould be my mind!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: It is a mind
That shall remain a poison where it is,
Not poison any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Shall remain!
Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you
His absolute 'shall'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas from the canon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Shall'!
O good but most unwise patricians! why,
You grave but reckless senators, have you thus
Given Hydra here to choose an officer,
That with his peremptory 'shall,' being but
The horn and noise o' the monster's, wants not spirit
To say he'll turn your current in a ditch,
And make your channel his? If he have power
Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake
Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd,
Be not as common fools; if you are not,
Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians,
If they be senators: and they are no less,
When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste
Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate,
And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,'
His popular 'shall' against a graver bench
Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself!
It makes the consuls base: and my soul aches
To know, when two authorities are up,
Neither supreme, how soon confusion
May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take
The one by the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, on to the market-place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Whoever gave that counsel, to give forth
The corn o' the storehouse gratis, as 'twas used
Sometime in Greece,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, no more of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Though there the people had more absolute power,
I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed
The ruin of the state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, shall the people give
One that speaks thus their voice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll give my reasons,
More worthier than their voices. They know the corn
Was not our recompense, resting well assured
That ne'er did service for't: being press'd to the war,
Even when the navel of the state was touch'd,
They would not thread the gates. This kind of service
Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' the war
Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd
Most valour, spoke not for them: the accusation
Which they have often made against the senate,
All cause unborn, could never be the motive
Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?
How shall this bisson multitude digest
The senate's courtesy? Let deeds express
What's like to be their words: 'we did request it;
We are the greater poll, and in true fear
They gave us our demands.' Thus we debase
The nature of our seats and make the rabble
Call our cares fears; which will in time
Break ope the locks o' the senate and bring in
The crows to peck the eagles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Enough, with over-measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, take more:
What may be sworn by, both divine and human,
Seal what I end withal! This double worship,
Where one part does disdain with cause, the other
Insult without all reason, where gentry, title, wisdom,
Cannot conclude but by the yea and no
Of general ignorance,--it must omit
Real necessities, and give way the while
To unstable slightness: purpose so barr'd,
it follows,
Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you,--
You that will be less fearful than discreet,
That love the fundamental part of state
More than you doubt the change on't, that prefer
A noble life before a long, and wish
To jump a body with a dangerous physic
That's sure of death without it, at once pluck out
The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick
The sweet which is their poison: your dishonour
Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state
Of that integrity which should become't,
Not having the power to do the good it would,
For the in which doth control't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Has said enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer
As traitors do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee!
What should the people do with these bald tribunes?
On whom depending, their obedience fails
To the greater bench: in a rebellion,
When what's not meet, but what must be, was law,
Then were they chosen: in a better hour,
Let what is meet be said it must be meet,
And throw their power i' the dust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Manifest treason!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This a consul? no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: The aediles, ho!
Let him be apprehended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, call the people:
in whose name myself
Attach thee as a traitorous innovator,
A foe to the public weal: obey, I charge thee,
And follow to thine answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hence, old goat!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senators, C
SPEECH.LINE: We'll surety him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Aged sir, hands off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones
Out of thy garments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Help, ye citizens!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a rabble of Citizens (Plebeians), with the AEdiles

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: On both sides more respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here's he that would take from you all your power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Seize him, AEdiles!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Down with him! down with him!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senators, C
SPEECH.LINE: Weapons, weapons, weapons!
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: They all bustle about CORIOLANUS, crying
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tribunes!' 'Patricians!' 'Citizens!' 'What, ho!'
'Sicinius!' 'Brutus!' 'Coriolanus!' 'Citizens!'
'Peace, peace, peace!' 'Stay, hold, peace!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What is about to be? I am out of breath;
Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes
To the people! Coriolanus, patience!
Speak, good Sicinius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hear me, people; peace!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak, speak, speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You are at point to lose your liberties:
Marcius would have all from you; Marcius,
Whom late you have named for consul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie, fie!
This is the way to kindle, not to quench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What is the city but the people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: True,
The people are the city.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: By the consent of all, we were establish'd
The people's magistrates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: You so remain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: And so are like to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: That is the way to lay the city flat;
To bring the roof to the foundation,
And bury all, which yet distinctly ranges,
In heaps and piles of ruin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This deserves death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Or let us stand to our authority,
Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce,
Upon the part o' the people, in whose power
We were elected theirs, Marcius is worthy
Of present death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore lay hold of him;
Bear him to the rock Tarpeian, and from thence
Into destruction cast him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: AEdiles, seize him!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Yield, Marcius, yield!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hear me one word;
Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: To BRUTUS Be that you seem, truly your
country's friend,
And temperately proceed to what you would
Thus violently redress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, those cold ways,
That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous
Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him,
And bear him to the rock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, I'll die here.
There's some among you have beheld me fighting:
Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Lay hands upon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Help Marcius, help,
You that be noble; help him, young and old!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Down with him, down with him!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: In this mutiny, the Tribunes, the AEdiles, and the People, are beat in

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, get you to your house; be gone, away!
All will be naught else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Get you gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Stand fast;
We have as many friends as enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sham it be put to that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: The gods forbid!
I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house;
Leave us to cure this cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: For 'tis a sore upon us,
You cannot tent yourself: be gone, beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, sir, along with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I would they were barbarians--as they are,
Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not,
Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Be gone;
Put not your worthy rage into your tongue;
One time will owe another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: On fair ground
I could beat forty of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I could myself
Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the
two tribunes:
But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic;
And manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands
Against a falling fabric. Will you hence,
Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend
Like interrupted waters and o'erbear
What they are used to bear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you, be gone:
I'll try whether my old wit be in request
With those that have but little: this must be patch'd
With cloth of any colour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, come away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: A Patrician
SPEECH.LINE: This man has marr'd his fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: His nature is too noble for the world:
He would not flatter Neptune for his trident,
Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth:
What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent;
And, being angry, does forget that ever
He heard the name of death.
Here's goodly work!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Patrician
SPEECH.LINE: I would they were abed!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance!
Could he not speak 'em fair?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS, with the rabble

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Where is this viper
That would depopulate the city and
Be every man himself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You worthy tribunes,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock
With rigorous hands: he hath resisted law,
And therefore law shall scorn him further trial
Than the severity of the public power
Which he so sets at nought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: He shall well know
The noble tribunes are the people's mouths,
And we their hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: He shall, sure on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, sir,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Peace!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt
With modest warrant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, how comes't that you
Have holp to make this rescue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hear me speak:
As I do know the consul's worthiness,
So can I name his faults,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Consul! what consul?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The consul Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: He consul!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, no, no, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people,
I may be heard, I would crave a word or two;
The which shall turn you to no further harm
Than so much loss of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Speak briefly then;
For we are peremptory to dispatch
This viperous traitor: to eject him hence
Were but one danger, and to keep him here
Our certain death: therefore it is decreed
He dies to-night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Now the good gods forbid
That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude
Towards her deserved children is enroll'd
In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam
Should now eat up her own!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He's a disease that must be cut away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, he's a limb that has but a disease;
Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy.
What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost--
Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath,
By many an ounce--he dropp'd it for his country;
And what is left, to lose it by his country,
Were to us all, that do't and suffer it,
A brand to the end o' the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This is clean kam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Merely awry: when he did love his country,
It honour'd him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The service of the foot
Being once gangrened, is not then respected
For what before it was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: We'll hear no more.
Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence:
Lest his infection, being of catching nature,
Spread further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: One word more, one word.
This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find
The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will too late
Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process;
Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out,
And sack great Rome with Romans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: If it were so,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What do ye talk?
Have we not had a taste of his obedience?
Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars
Since he could draw a sword, and is ill school'd
In bolted language; meal and bran together
He throws without distinction. Give me leave,
I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him
Where he shall answer, by a lawful form,
In peace, to his utmost peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Noble tribunes,
It is the humane way: the other course
Will prove too bloody, and the end of it
Unknown to the beginning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Menenius,
Be you then as the people's officer.
Masters, lay down your weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go not home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there:
Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed
In our first way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll bring him to you.
Let me desire your company: he must come,
Or what is worst will follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you, let's to him.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. A room in CORIOLANUS'S house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let them puff all about mine ears, present me
Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels,
Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock,
That the precipitation might down stretch
Below the beam of sight, yet will I still
Be thus to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: A Patrician
SPEECH.LINE: You do the nobler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I muse my mother
Does not approve me further, who was wont
To call them woollen vassals, things created
To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads
In congregations, to yawn, be still and wonder,
When one but of my ordinance stood up
To speak of peace or war.
I talk of you:
Why did you wish me milder? would you have me
False to my nature? Rather say I play
The man I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: O, sir, sir, sir,
I would have had you put your power well on,
Before you had worn it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: You might have been enough the man you are,
With striving less to be so; lesser had been
The thwartings of your dispositions, if
You had not show'd them how ye were disposed
Ere they lack'd power to cross you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let them hang.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: A Patrician
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and burn too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you have been too rough, something
too rough;
You must return and mend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: There's no remedy;
Unless, by not so doing, our good city
Cleave in the midst, and perish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Pray, be counsell'd:
I have a heart as little apt as yours,
But yet a brain that leads my use of anger
To better vantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well said, noble woman?
Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that
The violent fit o' the time craves it as physic
For the whole state, I would put mine armour on,
Which I can scarcely bear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: What must I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Return to the tribunes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what then? what then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Repent what you have spoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: For them! I cannot do it to the gods;
Must I then do't to them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: You are too absolute;
Though therein you can never be too noble,
But when extremities speak. I have heard you say,
Honour and policy, like unsever'd friends,
I' the war do grow together: grant that, and tell me,
In peace what each of them by the other lose,
That they combine not there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Tush, tush!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: A good demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: If it be honour in your wars to seem
The same you are not, which, for your best ends,
You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse,
That it shall hold companionship in peace
With honour, as in war, since that to both
It stands in like request?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why force you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Because that now it lies you on to speak
To the people; not by your own instruction,
Nor by the matter which your heart prompts you,
But with such words that are but rooted in
Your tongue, though but bastards and syllables
Of no allowance to your bosom's truth.
Now, this no more dishonours you at all
Than to take in a town with gentle words,
Which else would put you to your fortune and
The hazard of much blood.
I would dissemble with my nature where
My fortunes and my friends at stake required
I should do so in honour: I am in this,
Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles;
And you will rather show our general louts
How you can frown than spend a fawn upon 'em,
For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard
Of what that want might ruin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Noble lady!
Come, go with us; speak fair: you may salve so,
Not what is dangerous present, but the loss
Of what is past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: I prithee now, my son,
Go to them, with this bonnet in thy hand;
And thus far having stretch'd it--here be with them--
Thy knee bussing the stones--for in such business
Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant
More learned than the ears--waving thy head,
Which often, thus, correcting thy stout heart,
Now humble as the ripest mulberry
That will not hold the handling: or say to them,
Thou art their soldier, and being bred in broils
Hast not the soft way which, thou dost confess,
Were fit for thee to use as they to claim,
In asking their good loves, but thou wilt frame
Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far
As thou hast power and person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This but done,
Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours;
For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free
As words to little purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Prithee now,
Go, and be ruled: although I know thou hadst rather
Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf
Than flatter him in a bower. Here is Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I have been i' the market-place; and, sir,'tis fit
You make strong party, or defend yourself
By calmness or by absence: all's in anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Only fair speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I think 'twill serve, if he
Can thereto frame his spirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: He must, and will
Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce?
Must I with base tongue give my noble heart
A lie that it must bear? Well, I will do't:
Yet, were there but this single plot to lose,
This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it
And throw't against the wind. To the market-place!
You have put me now to such a part which never
I shall discharge to the life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, we'll prompt you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said
My praises made thee first a soldier, so,
To have my praise for this, perform a part
Thou hast not done before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I must do't:
Away, my disposition, and possess me
Some harlot's spirit! my throat of war be turn'd,
Which quired with my drum, into a pipe
Small as an eunuch, or the virgin voice
That babies lulls asleep! the smiles of knaves
Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears take up
The glasses of my sight! a beggar's tongue
Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees,
Who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his
That hath received an alms! I will not do't,
Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth
And by my body's action teach my mind
A most inherent baseness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: At thy choice, then:
To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour
Than thou of them. Come all to ruin; let
Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear
Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death
With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list
Thy valiantness was mine, thou suck'dst it from me,
But owe thy pride thyself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pray, be content:
Mother, I am going to the market-place;
Chide me no more. I'll mountebank their loves,
Cog their hearts from them, and come home beloved
Of all the trades in Rome. Look, I am going:
Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul;
Or never trust to what my tongue can do
I' the way of flattery further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Do your will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Away! the tribunes do attend you: arm yourself
To answer mildly; for they are prepared
With accusations, as I hear, more strong
Than are upon you yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: The word is 'mildly.' Pray you, let us go:
Let them accuse me by invention, I
Will answer in mine honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but mildly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, mildly be it then. Mildly!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. The same. The Forum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: In this point charge him home, that he affects
Tyrannical power: if he evade us there,
Enforce him with his envy to the people,
And that the spoil got on the Antiates
Was ne'er distributed.
What, will he come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: He's coming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: How accompanied?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: With old Menenius, and those senators
That always favour'd him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have you a catalogue
Of all the voices that we have procured
Set down by the poll?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: I have; 'tis ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Have you collected them by tribes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Assemble presently the people hither;
And when they bear me say 'It shall be so
I' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it either
For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them
If I say fine, cry 'Fine;' if death, cry 'Death.'
Insisting on the old prerogative
And power i' the truth o' the cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: I shall inform them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: And when such time they have begun to cry,
Let them not cease, but with a din confused
Enforce the present execution
Of what we chance to sentence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: Very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Make them be strong and ready for this hint,
When we shall hap to give 't them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go about it.
Put him to choler straight: he hath been used
Ever to conquer, and to have his worth
Of contradiction: being once chafed, he cannot
Be rein'd again to temperance; then he speaks
What's in his heart; and that is there which looks
With us to break his neck.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, here he comes.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, and COMINIUS, with Senators and Patricians

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Calmly, I do beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, as an ostler, that for the poorest piece
Will bear the knave by the volume. The honour'd gods
Keep Rome in safety, and the chairs of justice
Supplied with worthy men! plant love among 's!
Throng our large temples with the shows of peace,
And not our streets with war!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Senator
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: A noble wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Draw near, ye people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: List to your tribunes. Audience: peace, I say!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: First, hear me speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both Tribunes
SPEECH.LINE: Well, say. Peace, ho!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I be charged no further than this present?
Must all determine here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I do demand,
If you submit you to the people's voices,
Allow their officers and are content
To suffer lawful censure for such faults
As shall be proved upon you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Lo, citizens, he says he is content:
The warlike service he has done, consider; think
Upon the wounds his body bears, which show
Like graves i' the holy churchyard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Scratches with briers,
Scars to move laughter only.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Consider further,
That when he speaks not like a citizen,
You find him like a soldier: do not take
His rougher accents for malicious sounds,
But, as I say, such as become a soldier,
Rather than envy you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: What is the matter
That being pass'd for consul with full voice,
I am so dishonour'd that the very hour
You take it off again?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Answer to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Say, then: 'tis true, I ought so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: We charge you, that you have contrived to take
From Rome all season'd office and to wind
Yourself into a power tyrannical;
For which you are a traitor to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: How! traitor!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, temperately; your promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: The fires i' the lowest hell fold-in the people!
Call me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune!
Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths,
In thy hand clutch'd as many millions, in
Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say
'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free
As I do pray the gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Mark you this, people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: To the rock, to the rock with him!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Peace!
We need not put new matter to his charge:
What you have seen him do and heard him speak,
Beating your officers, cursing yourselves,
Opposing laws with strokes and here defying
Those whose great power must try him; even this,
So criminal and in such capital kind,
Deserves the extremest death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: But since he hath
Served well for Rome,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: What do you prate of service?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I talk of that, that know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: You?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the promise that you made your mother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Know, I pray you,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: I know no further:
Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death,
Vagabond exile, raying, pent to linger
But with a grain a day, I would not buy
Their mercy at the price of one fair word;
Nor cheque my courage for what they can give,
To have't with saying 'Good morrow.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: For that he has,
As much as in him lies, from time to time
Envied against the people, seeking means
To pluck away their power, as now at last
Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence
Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers
That do distribute it; in the name o' the people
And in the power of us the tribunes, we,
Even from this instant, banish him our city,
In peril of precipitation
From off the rock Tarpeian never more
To enter our Rome gates: i' the people's name,
I say it shall be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: It shall be so, it shall be so; let him away:
He's banish'd, and it shall be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hear me, my masters, and my common friends,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He's sentenced; no more hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let me speak:
I have been consul, and can show for Rome
Her enemies' marks upon me. I do love
My country's good with a respect more tender,
More holy and profound, than mine own life,
My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase,
And treasure of my loins; then if I would
Speak that,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: We know your drift: speak what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd,
As enemy to the people and his country:
It shall be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: It shall be so, it shall be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: You common cry of curs! whose breath I hate
As reek o' the rotten fens, whose loves I prize
As the dead carcasses of unburied men
That do corrupt my air, I banish you;
And here remain with your uncertainty!
Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts!
Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes,
Fan you into despair! Have the power still
To banish your defenders; till at length
Your ignorance, which finds not till it feels,
Making not reservation of yourselves,
Still your own foes, deliver you as most
Abated captives to some nation
That won you without blows! Despising,
For you, the city, thus I turn my back:
There is a world elsewhere.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt CORIOLANUS, COMINIUS, MENENIUS, Senators, and Patricians

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AEdile
SPEECH.LINE: The people's enemy is gone, is gone!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Our enemy is banish'd! he is gone! Hoo! hoo!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Shouting, and throwing up their caps

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, see him out at gates, and follow him,
As he hath followed you, with all despite;
Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard
Attend us through the city.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come; let's see him out at gates; come.
The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rome. Before a gate of the city.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter CORIOLANUS, VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, MENENIUS, COMINIUS, with the young Nobility of Rome

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast
With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother,
Where is your ancient courage? you were used
To say extremity was the trier of spirits;
That common chances common men could bear;
That when the sea was calm all boats alike
Show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows,
When most struck home, being gentle wounded, craves
A noble cunning: you were used to load me
With precepts that would make invincible
The heart that conn'd them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: O heavens! O heavens!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay! prithee, woman,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome,
And occupations perish!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: What, what, what!
I shall be loved when I am lack'd. Nay, mother.
Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say,
If you had been the wife of Hercules,
Six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved
Your husband so much sweat. Cominius,
Droop not; adieu. Farewell, my wife, my mother:
I'll do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius,
Thy tears are salter than a younger man's,
And venomous to thine eyes. My sometime general,
I have seen thee stem, and thou hast oft beheld
Heart-hardening spectacles; tell these sad women
'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes,
As 'tis to laugh at 'em. My mother, you wot well
My hazards still have been your solace: and
Believe't not lightly--though I go alone,
Like to a lonely dragon, that his fen
Makes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen--your son
Will or exceed the common or be caught
With cautelous baits and practise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: My first son.
Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius
With thee awhile: determine on some course,
More than a wild exposture to each chance
That starts i' the way before thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: O the gods!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COMINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll follow thee a month, devise with thee
Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us
And we of thee: so if the time thrust forth
A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send
O'er the vast world to seek a single man,
And lose advantage, which doth ever cool
I' the absence of the needer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fare ye well:
Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full
Of the wars' surfeits, to go rove with one
That's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.
Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and
My friends of noble touch, when I am forth,
Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you, come.
While I remain above the ground, you shall
Hear from me still, and never of me aught
But what is like me formerly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: That's worthily
As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep.
If I could shake off but one seven years
From these old arms and legs, by the good gods,
I'ld with thee every foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CORIOLANUS
SPEECH.LINE: Give me thy hand: Come.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The same. A street near the gate.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter SICINIUS, BRUTUS, and an AEdile

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them all home; he's gone, and we'll no further.
The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sided
In his behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Now we have shown our power,
Let us seem humbler after it is done
Than when it was a-doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them home:
Say their great enemy is gone, and they
Stand in their ancient strength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Dismiss them home.
Here comes his mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let's not meet her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: They say she's mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: They have ta'en note of us: keep on your way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: O, ye're well met: the hoarded plague o' the gods
Requite your love!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace; be not so loud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: If that I could for weeping, you should hear,--
Nay, and you shall hear some.
Will you be gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: To SICINIUS You shall stay too: I would I had the power
To say so to my husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Are you mankind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, fool; is that a shame? Note but this fool.
Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship
To banish him that struck more blows for Rome
Than thou hast spoken words?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: O blessed heavens!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: More noble blows than ever thou wise words;
And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what; yet go:
Nay, but thou shalt stay too: I would my son
Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him,
His good sword in his hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIRGILIA
SPEECH.LINE: What then!
He'ld make an end of thy posterity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Bastards and all.
Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I would he had continued to his country
As he began, and not unknit himself
The noble knot he made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I would he had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: 'I would he had'! 'Twas you incensed the rabble:
Cats, that can judge as fitly of his worth
As I can of those mysteries which heaven
Will not have earth to know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pray, let us go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Now, pray, sir, get you gone:
You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, hear this:--
As far as doth the Capitol exceed
The meanest house in Rome, so far my son--
This lady's husband here, this, do you see--
Whom you have banish'd, does exceed you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, we'll leave you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SICINIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why stay we to be baited
With one that wants her wits?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Take my prayers with you.
I would the gods had nothing else to do
But to confirm my curses! Could I meet 'em
But once a-day, it would unclog my heart
Of what lies heavy to't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You have told them home;
And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VOLUMNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself,
And so shall starve with feeding. Come, let's go:
Leave this faint puling and lament as I do,
In anger, Juno-like. Come, come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MENENIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie, fie!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. A highway between Rome and Antium.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Roman and a Volsce, meeting

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roman
SPEECH.LINE: I know you well, sir, and you know
me: your name, I think, is Adrian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volsce
SPEECH.LINE: It is so, sir: truly, I have forgot you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roman
SPEECH.LINE: I am a Roman; and my services are,
as you are, against 'em: know you me yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volsce
SPEECH.LINE: Nicanor? no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roman
SPEECH.LINE: The same, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volsce
SPEECH.LINE: You had more beard when I last saw you; but your
favour is well approved by your tongue. What's the
news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian state,
to find you out there: you have well saved me a
day's journey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roman
SPEECH.LINE: There hath been in Rome strange insurrections; the
people against the senators, patricians, and nobles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volsce
SPEECH.LINE: Hath been! is it ended, then? Our state thinks not
so: they are in a most warlike preparation, and
hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roman
SPEECH.LINE: The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing
would make it flame again: for the nobles receive
so to heart the banishment of that worthy
Coriolanus, that they are in a ripe aptness to take
all power from the people and to pluck from them
their tribunes for ever. This lies glowing, I can
tell you, and is almost mature for the violent
breaking out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volsce
SPEECH.LINE: Coriolanus banished!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roman
SPEECH.LINE: Banished, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volsce
SPEECH.LINE: You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roman
SPEECH.LINE: The day serves well for them now. I have heard it
said, the fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is
